k.explanation: karat
The 11th letter of the modern English alphabet.
Any of the speech sounds represented by the letter k.
The 11th in a series.
Something shaped like the letter K.
chem. , the symbol for potassium (NL. kalium ).
lowercase ] In meteorology , of cumulus ( c being used for cirrus ).
king, knight , etc.: as, K. G., Knight of the Garter.
math., k is generally a constant coefficient. It is also a unit vector perpendicular to i and j.
electricity , of kathode ( cathode , which see) and kathodic ( cathodic ).
mathematics : The Lemoine point in geometry.
mineralogy , the middle letter of the general symbol hkl , given to the face of a crystal in the system of Miller. See symbol , 7.
: The symbol usually employed for moment of inertia. The letter K is used by some writers as a symbol of electrostatic capacity , but C is now almost universally adopted for this quantity.
magnetic susceptibility.
absolute temperature.
The eleventh letter of the basic modern Latin alphabet .
voiceless velar plosive .
The eleventh letter of the English alphabet , called kay and written in the Latin script .
The first letter of callsigns allocated to American broadcast television and radio stations west of the Mississippi river.
The ordinal number eleventh , derived from this letter of the English alphabet , called kay and written in the Latin script .
The eleventh letter of the English alphabet.
A kilobyte (more formally KB or kB ).
kilometre or kilometres .
thousand or thousands .
The SI measurement value of 1,000
See K
Abbreviation of okay . (Also spelled 'kay .)
a unit of information equal to 1024 bytes
denoting a quantity consisting of 1,000 items or units

a light soft silver-white metallic element of the alkali metal group; oxidizes rapidly in air and reacts violently with water; is abundant in nature in combined forms occurring in sea water and in carnallite and kainite and sylvite
a unit of information equal to 1000 bytes
the basic unit of thermodynamic temperature adopted under the Systeme International d'Unites
the cardinal number that is the product of 10 and 100
the 11th letter of the Roman alphabet
street names for ketamine

ka.explanation: ko , for quoth (often for quoth he ).
An unknown god; an epithet of Prajapati and Brahma.

A spiritual aspect of the individual, living within the body during life, and surviving the body after death. It was believed to be one of two spirits inhabiting the body, the other being the ba , which deserts teh body at death.
a spiritual part of the soul in Egyptian mythology, which survived after death
To serve, in the phrase "Ka me, ka thee".
unknown god; an epithet of Prajapati and Brahma

kabaka.explanation: The title of the king of Buganda.

kabala.explanation: an esoteric theosophy of rabbinical origin based on the Hebrew scriptures and developed between the 7th and 18th centuries
an esoteric or occult matter resembling the Kabbalah that is traditionally secret

kabaragoya.explanation: The water monitor , a reptile with scientific name Varanus slavator

kabassou.explanation: A xenurine armadillo, as Xenurus unicinctus or X. hispidus.

kabbala.explanation: an esoteric theosophy of rabbinical origin based on the Hebrew scriptures and developed between the 7th and 18th centuries
an esoteric or occult matter resembling the Kabbalah that is traditionally secret

kabbalah.explanation: A body of mystical teachings of rabbinical origin, often based on an esoteric interpretation of the Hebrew Scriptures.
A secret doctrine resembling these teachings.

kabeljou.explanation: A type of fish from southern Africa, scientific name Argyrosomus coronus

kabiki.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, Mimusops Elengi , a tree having sweet-scented flowers, which retain their odor when dried and from which a scent is prepared by distillation.

kabob.explanation: cubes of meat marinated and cooked on a skewer usually with vegetables

kabuki.explanation: A form of Japanese theatre in which elaborately costumed male performers use stylized movements, dances, and songs in order to enact tragedies and comedies.

kachina.explanation: Any of numerous deified ancestral spirits of the Pueblo peoples, believed to reside in the pueblo for part of each year.
A masked dancer believed to embody a particular spirit during a religious ceremony.
A carved doll in the costume of a particular spirit, usually presented as a gift to a child.
A vaguely ancestral anthropomorphic spirit being , associated with clouds and rain or personifying the power in the sun, the earth, or corn (among other things).
A wooden doll, as might be given to a child, which represents such a being.
A masked dancer who represents such a being in a ceremonial dance or masked ceremony.
a carved doll wearing the costume of a particular Pueblo spirit; usually presented to a child as a gift
a deified spirit of the Pueblo people
a masked dancer during a Pueblo religious ceremony who is thought to embody some particular spirit

kadarite.explanation: One of a Mohammedan school or sect which denies the doctrine of predestination and maintains that of free will.

kaddish.explanation: A Jewish prayer recited during services, and when mourning the death of a close relative.

kadsura.explanation: A genus of climbing shrubs of the order Magnoliaceæ , tribe Schizandreæ : distinguished from Schizandra , the only other genus of the tribe, by the berry-like and globose, instead of elongated, fruit. There are about 7 species, natives of tropical Asia.

kaempferol.explanation: A flavonoid , isolated from tea and other plants, that may reduce the risk of heart disease

kaf.explanation: The twenty-second letter of the Arabic alphabet. ك

kaffeeklatsch.explanation: An afternoon party in Germany at which coffee or tea is drunk; an ‘afternoon tea’ in Germany.

kaffir.explanation: One of a race which, with the Hottentots and Bushmen, inhabit South Africa. They inhabit the country north of Cape Colony, the name being now specifically applied to the tribes living between Cape Colony and Natal, including the Ponda, Xosa, and Tembu; but the Zulus of Natal are true Kaffirs.
One of a race inhabiting Kafiristan in Central Asia.
Any Black African; -- a disparaging and offensive term used by white South Africans.
a Cape Colony name for Indian millet.

kaffir.category: South Africa, pejorative, offensive, ethnic slur

kaffir.explanation: important for human and animal food; growth habit and stem form similar to Indian corn but having sawtooth-edged leaves
an offensive and insulting term for any Black African

kaffiyeh.explanation: In Syria, a small shawl or scarf worn about the head, and bound with a colored cord.
an Arab headdress consisting of a square piece of cloth folded into a triangle and fastened over the crown by an agal

kafila.explanation: A train of loaded camels; a caravan. Also caffila, cafilah, kafilah.

kafir.explanation: plural The stock-exchange term for South African mine shares.
An unbeliever; an infidel: applied malevolently by Mohammedans to Christians and pagan negroes.

One of a South African race, inhabiting parts of Cape Colony, Natal, and neighboring lands: so called originally by the Mohammedan inhabitants of eastern Africa, on account of their refusal to accept the faith of Mohammed.
The language of the Kafirs, a branch of the South African or Bantu family. It is also called Zulu-Kafir .
One of a race inhabiting Kafiristan, a mountainous region on the northeast of Afghanistan, who have always maintained their independence and resisted conversion to Mohammedanism.
Infidel , pagan , non-believer ; a non- Muslim aside from ahl al-kitab ( Christians , Jews , etc.).
a member of the Kafir people in northeastern Afghanistan
an offensive and insulting term for any Black African

kafirin.explanation: Any of a group of storage proteins found in sorghum

kafiz.explanation: An Arabian measure of capacity, nearly equal, according to Queipo, to 33 liters. According to Eliyâh and the Sheikh Hasan el Jabarti, generally 90 rotl (which see), or 8 makkoûk, but sometimes less. Also spelled cafiz .

kafta.explanation: The leaves of Catha edulis. Also cafta, khat.

kaftan.explanation: A long tunic worn in the Eastern Mediterranean .
A long dress or shirt similar in style to those worn in the Eastern Mediterranean.
a woman's dress style that imitates the caftan cloaks worn by men in the Near East
a (cotton or silk) cloak with full sleeves and sash reaching down to the ankles; worn by men in the Levant

kago.explanation: A small basketwork palanquin slung from a pole carried on the shoulders of two men.

kagu.explanation: A remarkable grallatorial bird, Rhinochetus jubatus , the sole member of the family Rhinochetidæ peculiar to New Caledonia.

A singular, crested, grallatorial bird (Rhinochetos jubatus) , native of New Caledonia. It is gray above, paler beneath, and the feathers of the wings and tail are handsomely barred with brown, black, and gray. It is allied to the sun bittern.
A New Caledonian endemic bird species , Rhynochetos jubatus , the only surviving member of the family Rhynochetidae .

kagura.explanation: One of the oldest dances of Japan, which is still to be seen in certain temples.
A kind of Shinto theatrical dance in Japan .

kahau.explanation: The proboscis-monkey, Nasalis larvatus : adopted as a book-name.

A long-nosed monkey ( Nasalis larvatus , formerly Semnopithecus nasalis ), native of Borneo. The general color of the body is bright chestnut, with the under parts, shoulders, and sides of the head, golden yellow, and the top of the head and upper part of the back brown. Called also proboscis monkey . It is now an endangered species.

kahikatea.explanation: The coniferous tree Podocarpus dacrydioides of New Zealand, called by the colonists white pine.
Dacrycarpus dacrydioides, a coniferous tree endemic to New Zealand .
New Zealand evergreen valued for its light easily worked wood

kahuna.explanation: Priest of high rank , or often said of an expert in a profession , such as dentistry .

kaid.explanation: In northern Africa, the head or chief of a tribe, or the governor of a town or local district.
A local governor or leader, especially in North Africa or Moorish Spain; an alcaide .

kaif.explanation: Undisturbed quiescence, regarded as a state of high happiness.

kaikawaka.explanation: Libocedrus bidwillii, the New Zealand cedar, an evergreen coniferous tree .

kail.explanation: p1. A game in which nine holes ranged in threes are made in the ground, and an iron ball is rolled in among them.
The Himalayan Pinus excelsa , or Bhutan pine.
A kind of headless cabbage. Same as kale , 1.
A broth made with kail or other vegetables; hence, any broth; also, a dinner.
A broth made with kale or other vegetables; hence, any broth ; also, a dinner .
a hardy cabbage with coarse curly leaves that do not form a head

kaimakam.explanation: An officer in the Turkish service, especially a lieutenant-colonel.
An administrative officer in Turkey; specifically, the administrator of a subdivision of a vilayet.
the governor of a sanjak in Turkey

kain.explanation: Poultry, etc., required by the lease to be paid in kind by a tenant to his landlord.
poultry , etc., required by the lease to be paid in kind by a tenant to the landlord

kainit.explanation: Salts of potassium used in the manufacture of fertilizers.
Salts of potassium used in the manufacture of fertilizers .

kainite.explanation: A white, gray, pink, or black mineral, MgSO 4 · KCl · 3H 2 O, used as a fertilizer and a source of potassium compounds.
A hydrous magnesium sulphate with potassium chlorid, occurring in beds of considerable extent at the salt-mines of Stassfurt, Germany.
A compound salt consisting chiefly of potassium chloride and magnesium sulphate, occurring at the Stassfurt salt mines in Prussian Saxony.
A saline evaporite , consisting of magnesium sulphate and potassium chloride with the chemical formula Mg S O 4· K Cl ·3H2O, found in German salt mines .
a white mineral consisting of magnesium sulphate and potassium chloride; a source of potassium salts; used as a fertilizer

kainogenesis.explanation: introduction during embryonic development of characters or structure not present in the earlier evolutionary history of the strain or species (such as the addition of the placenta in mammalian evolution)

kairine.explanation: A whitish crystalline powder (C 10 H 13 ON.HCl. + H 2 O), bitter-salt in taste, soluble in water and alcohol, and used in medicine as an antipyretic.
A pale buff or white crystalline alkaloid derived from quinoline, and used as an antipyretic in medicine.
A derivative of tetrahydro - quinoline (C10H13NO). It was used as an antipyretic .

kairolin.explanation: A colorless liquid, C 9 H 10 NCH 3 , prepared by the action of methyl iodide on tetrahydroquinoline; methyltetra-hydroquinoline. It boils at 242–244° C. under 720 millimeters pressure, and is used in medicine as a febrifuge.

kairoline.explanation: An organic base obtained from quinoline. It is used as a febrifuge, and resembles kairine.
An organic base obtained from quinoline , resembling kairine and used as a febrifuge .

kairos.explanation: A time when conditions are right for the accomplishment of a crucial action; the opportune and decisive moment.

kaiser.explanation: An emperor of a German -speaking country, particularly the Holy Roman Empire (962-1806), the Austrian Empire (1806-1918), and the German Empire (1871-1918).
a person who exercises or tries to exercise absolute authority ; autocrat .

kaiserdom.explanation: The dignity, rank or office of a kaiser ; the state of being a kaiser.

kaisership.explanation: The office of kaiser or emperor.

kaitaka.explanation: A mat of fine texture made by New Zealanders and often worn by them as a cloak.

kaiwhiria.explanation: In New Zealand, an evergreen shrub or small tree, Hedycarya arborea , belonging to the family Monimiaceæ , with opposite leaves, axillary panicles of diœcious flowers, and fruit in the form of rod drupes. The wood is finely marked and is suitable for veneering.

kaj.explanation: spirits of storm and wind; can be both ugly and beautiful

kaka.explanation: A brownish-green New Zealand parrot (Nestor meridionalis).
A parrot of the genus Nestor , peculiar to New Zealand. The common kaka is N. hypopolius , and the mountain kaka N. notabilis. See Nestor .
A New Zealand parrot of the genus Nestor, especially the brown parrot ( Nestor meridionalis ).
Any of four taxa of birds in the genus Nestor in the parrot family confined to New Zealand and adjacent islands.

kakapo.explanation: A nocturnal, flightless New Zealand parrot (Strigops habroptila) with greenish plumage.
The owl-parrot or ground-parrot of New Zealand, Stringops habroptilus , a large and noteworthy parrot, by some made the type of a family Stringopidæ , distinct from the Psittacidæ.

A singular nocturnal parrot ( Strigops habroptilus ), native of New Zealand. It lives in holes during the day, but is active at night. It resembles an owl in its colors and general appearance. It has large wings, but can fly only a short distance. Called also owl parrot , night parrot , and night kaka .
A large flightless parrot , Strigops habroptilus, with greenish plumage, that is nocturnal and native to New Zealand .

kakarali.explanation: A tree of British Guiana, Lecythis Ollaria.

kakaralli.explanation: A kind of wood common in Demerara, durable in salt water, because not subject to the depredations of the sea worm and barnacle.
A kind of wood common in Demerara , durable in salt water because not consumed by sea worms or barnacles .

kakariki.explanation: A Maori name, adopted to some extent for a small green parrot of the genus Platycercus. P. novæhollandiæ is the more common species.

kakawahie.explanation: One of the honey-suckers, Oreomyza flammed , Eeculiar to the Sandwich Islands, which inhabits the island of Molokai.

kakemono.explanation: A Japanese scroll that displays painting or calligraphy, hung vertically on a wall.
A Japanese wall-picture or decoration, painted in transparent colors on a band of silk, gauze, or paper, and mounted on a roller
a Japanese (paper or silk) wall hanging; usually narrow with a picture or writing on it and a roller at the bottom

kaki.explanation: A tree (Diospyros kaki) native to China, widely cultivated for its large edible fruit, having orange to reddish skin, orange flesh, and an enlarged, persistent calyx.
The persimmon of Japan, or Chinese date, Diospyros Kaki , or its fruit.
small deciduous Asiatic tree bearing large red or orange edible astringent fruit
blackish stilt of New Zealand sometimes considered a color phase of the white-headed stilt

kakidrosis.explanation: A secretion of sweat of a disagreeable odor .

kakistocracy.explanation: Government by the least qualified or most unprincipled citizens.
Government by the worst men in the state: opposed to aristocracy , government by the best men.
Government under the control of a nation's worst or least-qualified citizens.

kal.explanation: An abbreviation of kalends . See calends .

kalach.explanation: traditional East Slavic bread shaped like a padlock or various kinds of wheels. Other Slavic nations have similar but not identical types of pastry, e.g. Czech or Slovak koláč / koláč , Polish kołacz , Bulgarian колач , Serbo-Croatian колач / kolač , etc.

kaladana.explanation: A species of morning-glory, Ipomæa ( Pharbitis ) Nil , found in the warmer parts of the Old World.

kalamalo.explanation: A Hawaiian grass. Same as emoloa .

kalamansanai.explanation: A name in the Philippine Islands of several valuable timber-trees, especially of Terminalia Calamansanay , of the family Combretaceæ , with simple pointed leaves clustered at the ends of the branches, spikes of inconspicuous flowers, and winged, nut-like fruit.

kalamkari.explanation: Color-decoration of certain special kinds in Indian countries; specifically, a chintz of which the pattern is produced by many separate dyeings, the ground being covered in places by repellent preparations, and also by printing from small blocks.
a type of hand-printed cotton cloth from India

kalanchoe.explanation: Any of several succulent plants of the genus Kalanchoe, often cultivated as houseplants for their fleshy leaves and colorful flowers.
A genus of tropical herbs or shrubs belonging to the natural order Crassulaceæ , or orpine family, differing from most other plants of the order by having the calyx 4-parted.
[ lowercase ] A plant of this genus.
Any of the genus Kalanchoe of tropical , succulent flowering plants .

kalapooian.explanation: a Penutian language spoken by the Kalapuya

kalasie.explanation: A long-tailed monkey of Borneo ( Semnopithecus rubicundus ). It has a tuft of long hair on the head.
A long-tailed monkey Semnopithecus rubicundus native to Borneo

kale.explanation: A plant (Brassica oleracea var. acephala) in the mustard family, having dark green, spreading, usually crinkled leaves that are eaten as a vegetable.

In Scotland, loosely, cabbage in general, and by extension any kind of greens; specifically, both there and elsewhere, any variety of cabbage with curled or wrinkled leaves not forming compact heads like the common cabbage, nor yielding a fleshy edible inflorescence like the cauliflower and broccoli, and usually having a long stalk; borecole.

A broth made in Scotland in which kale or cabbage is a principal ingredient; hence, any soup, no matter of what composed, and, by a further extension, dinner: as, will you come and tak' your kale wi' me?
Brassica oleracea , the cabbage-plant, in its wild state.
A variety of cabbage in which the leaves do not form a head, being nearly the original or wild form of the species.
a European cruciferous herb ( Crambe maritima ), often used as a pot herb; sea cabbage.
An edible plant, similar to cabbage , with curled leaves that do not form a dense head (Brassica oleracea var. acephala)
a hardy cabbage with coarse curly leaves that do not form a head

kaleege.explanation: A pheasant of the genus Euplocamus and that section of the genus called Gallophasis , closely related to the silver-pheasants and firebacks.
One of several species of large, crested, Asiatic pheasants, belonging to the genus Euplocamus, and allied to the firebacks.

kaleidophone.explanation: An instrument invented by Sir Charles Wheatstone for exhibiting the vibrations of an elastic plate or rod, in order to illustrate the phenomena of sound-waves.
A device, consisting of a reflective ball attached to a vibrating rod or plate, that produces optical figures that correspond to the mode of vibration of the rod or plate

kaleidoscope.explanation: A tube-shaped optical instrument that is rotated to produce a succession of symmetrical designs by means of mirrors reflecting the constantly changing patterns made by small objects, such as beads or bits of colored glass, at one end of the tube.
A constantly changing set of colors.
A series of changing phases or events.
An optical instrument creating and exhibiting, by reflection, a variety of beautiful colors and symmetrical forms.

An instrument invented by Sir David Brewster, which contains loose fragments of colored glass, etc., and reflecting surfaces so arranged that changes of position exhibit its contents in an endless variety of beautiful colors and symmetrical forms. It has been much employed in arts of design.
A tube of mirrors containing loose coloured beads etc. that is rotated to produce a succession of symmetrical designs
A constantly changing set of colours , or other things
a complex pattern of constantly changing colors and shapes
an optical toy in a tube; it produces symmetrical patterns as bits of colored glass are reflected by mirrors

kaleidoscopic.explanation: kaleidoscopic views; kaleidoscopic combinations of color.
Of, pertaining to, or formed by, a kaleidoscope; variegated.
Of, relating to, or produced by a kaleidoscope .
Brightly coloured and continuously changing in pattern, as if in a kaleidoscope.

kaleidoscopically.explanation: In a kaleidoscopic , continuously changing manner.

kalekah.explanation: A name for the Sanskrit alphabet.

kalewife.explanation: A woman who sells vegetables; a marketwoman; a huckstress.

kali.explanation: The prickly glasswort (Salsola kali or Kali turgida).

kalian.explanation: A name for the Eastern tobacco-pipe in which the smoke is drawn through water. See hooka and narghile.
A pipe with a long flexible tube connected to a container where the smoke is cooled by passing through water. See also hookah .
an oriental tobacco pipe with a long flexible tube connected to a container where the smoke is cooled by passing through water

kaliborite.explanation: A massive borate of magnesium and potassium: probably identical with heintzite .

kalidium.explanation: In the florideous algæ an oval capsule or cystocarp containing undivided spores.

kalif.explanation: the civil and religious leader of a Muslim state considered to be a representative of Allah on earth

kaligenous.explanation: Forming alkalies with oxygen, as some metals.
Forming alkalis with oxygen , as some metals do.

kalimba.explanation: A type of thumb piano, similar to a mbira .

kalinite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing aluminum , hydrogen , oxygen , potassium , and sulfur .

kaliophilite.explanation: A silicate of aluminium and potassium, allied to nephelite, found in volcanic bombs ejected from Monte Somma, Vesuvius.
a rare mineral , a form of KAlSiO4, found in volcanic rocks in parts of Italy

kaliph.explanation: the civil and religious leader of a Muslim state considered to be a representative of Allah on earth

kalium.explanation: Potassium: from this name its symbol K is derived.
Potassium; -- so called by the German chemists.

kallidin.explanation: A decapeptide kinin , produced in the kidneys , that causes dilation of renal blood vessels and increased water excretion

kallilite.explanation: A sulphobismuthid of nickel, NiBiS, which occurs in bluish-gray metallic masses at the Friedrich mine near Schönstein, Germany.

kalmia.explanation: Any plant in the taxonomic genus Kalmia .

kalmuck.explanation: A kind of shaggy cloth resembling bearskin

kalo.explanation: For words beginning thus, see calo- .

kalokagathia.explanation: A Platonic teaching based on philosophy of a bodily , moral and spiritual whole.

kalon.explanation: ideal perfect beauty in the physical and moral sense, especially as perceived by Greek philosophers

kalong.explanation: A general name of the large fruit-bats, fox-bats, flying-foxes, or roussettes belonging to the genus Pteropus.
A fruit bat, esp. the Indian edible fruit bat ( Pteropus edulis ).
A fruit bat , especially the Indian edible fruit bat (Pteropus edulis).

kalpa.explanation: In Hindu chron. , a day of Brahma, a period of 4,320,000,000 years, equivalent to a thousand great ages ( mahāyuga ); an eon.
One of the Brahmanic eons, a period of 4,320,000,000 years. At the end of each Kalpa the world is annihilated.

kalpis.explanation: In Gr. archæol. , a water-vase, usually of large size, resembling the hydria, and like it having three handles, but differing from the hydria in that the posterior handle does not extend above the rim.

kalsomine.explanation: Whitewash , an inexpensive form of white paint that is simple to compound and is used on wooden surfaces such as picket fences or park benches as well as plaster surfaces.
To apply kalsomine to a surface.

kalsomined.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kalsomine .

kalumpang.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, Sterculia fœtida , a tree with horizontal whorls of branches and digitate leaves.
large tree of Old World tropics having foul-smelling orange-red blossoms followed by red pods enclosing oil-rich seeds sometimes used as food

kalumpit.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, Terminalia Bellerica , a tree belonging to the Combretaceæ , and yielding edible almond-like nuts. See belleric, ink-nut , and myrobalan.

kalyptra.explanation: In ancient Greek costume , a veil of thin stuff very commonly worn to cover the hair.

kam.explanation: An obsolete form of came preterit of come .

kama.explanation: A sickle -like weapon, originally used as a tool for cutting weeds.

kamaaina.explanation: A native-born or longtime resident of the Hawaiian Islands.

kamala.explanation: An Asian tree (Mallotus philippensis) that bears a hairy capsular fruit from which a vermifugal powder is obtained.
The red dusty hairs of the capsules of an East Indian tree ( Mallotus Philippinensis ) used for dyeing silk. It is violently emetic, and is used in the treatment of tapeworm.

kamarezite.explanation: A hydrous copper sulphate allied to langite: found near Laurium, Greece.

kamassi.explanation: A South African tree, Gonioma Kamassi , of the dogbane family, with fragrant flowers, and a hard, tough, and close-grained yellow wood, which is used in cabinet-work, for the handles of tools, etc.

kame.explanation: A short ridge or mound of sand and gravel deposited during the melting of glacial ice.
A peculiar elongated ridge, made up of detrital material. See eskar , and horseback , 2.
A round hill or short ridge of sand or gravel deposited by a melting glacier .

kami.explanation: Any of the sacred beings worshiped in Shintoism, conceived as spirits abiding in natural phenomena and sometimes in people with extraordinary qualities.
A lord; a title applied by the Japanese to daimios and governors.

A term used by the Japanese to designate all the gods or celestial beings who formed and peopled Japan; the descendants of these gods, the mikados and the imperial family, as terrestrial kami; and such heroes and worthies as have been deified by the mikados.

[ capitalized ] [=Chin . shin , god, spirit.] The name used by the Protestant missionaries and the native Protestant Christians of Japan for the Supreme Being; God: the term used by Roman Catholics is Tenshu , or Lord of Heaven, whence Roman Catholics are known as the Tenshū -kio , or ‘Lord-of-Heaven sect.’

A title given to the celestial gods of the first mythical dynasty of Japan and extended to the demigods of the second dynasty, and then to the long line of spiritual princes still represented by the mikado.
An animistic God or spirit in the Shinto religion of Japan .
A basic origami paper , usually printed with a colour or pattern on one side.
one the Shinto deities (including mythological beings, spirits of distinguished men, forces of nature)

kamias.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, the bilimbi, Averrhoa Bilimbi , a small tree belonging to the sorrel family, having pinnately compound, sensitive leaves, clusters of crimson flowers, and pleasantly acid fruit, with the flavor of sorrel, which is eaten in the form of preserves. Also called kalamias . See bilimbi and Averrhoa.

kamichi.explanation: The horned screamer, Palamedea cornuta. Also written kamachi, kamechi.

A curious South American bird ( Anhima or Palamedea cornuta ), often domesticated by the natives and kept with poultry, which it defends against birds of prey. It has a long, slender, hornlike ornament on its head, and two sharp spurs on each wing. Although its beak, feet, and legs resemble those of gallinaceous birds, it is related in anatomical characters to the ducks and geese (Anseres). Called also horned screamer . The name is sometimes applied also to the chaja . See chaja , and screamer .
A South American bird with a long, slender, horn -like ornament on its head and two sharp spurs on each wing .

kamik.explanation: Eskimo boots of sealskin or caribou-skin reaching up to the knee or to near the hip.

kamikaze.explanation: A Japanese pilot trained in World War II to make a suicidal crash attack, especially upon a ship.
An airplane loaded with explosives to be piloted in a suicide attack.
An extremely reckless person who seems to court death.
Of or relating to a suicidal air attack.
So reckless in behavior or actions as to be suicidal.
An attack requiring the suicide of the one carrying it out, especially when done with an aircraft.
One who makes an attack requiring his suicide , especially when done with an aircraft.
a fighter plane used for suicide missions by Japanese pilots in World War II
a pilot trained and willing to cause a suicidal crash

kamis.explanation: The loose shirt, having sleeves reaching to the wrist, worn by men of Moslem nations. It is made of linen or cotton, or sometimes of a fabric of cotton and silk, etc.

kampong.explanation: A Malay village, such as is found in Malaysia , Brunei , and parts of Indonesia

kamptulicon.explanation: A kind of floor-cloth composed of india-rubber, gutta-percha, and ground cork.
A kind of elastic floor cloth, made of India rubber, gutta-percha, linseed oil, and powdered cork.
A kind of elastic floorcloth , made of India rubber , gutta-percha , linseed oil , and powdered cork .

kampylite.explanation: A variety of mimetite or arseniate of lead in hexagonal prisms of a fine orange yellow.

kamsin.explanation: A hot southwesterly wind in Egypt, coming from the Sahara.

kan.explanation: In Holland, the name given to the liter when used as a measure of capacity for liquids.
In Java, a measure of capacity equal to 0.35 of a United States gallon.

kana.explanation: Japanese syllabic writing. The characters are simplified kanji and are usually used with kanji primarily to write inflections, particles, and function words and to show the pronunciations of some kanji and of all foreign words.
Any of the characters used in this system.
Japanese writing as distinguished from Chinese, which is also used in Japan.
The hiragana and katakana syllabaries . These are used to write Japanese words and particles using characters that represent syllables. Kana are derived from kanji .

kanaka.explanation: A South Pacific Islander, especially a labourer in Australia or Canada.

kanamycin.explanation: A water-soluble broad-spectrum antibiotic, C 18 H 36 O 11 N 4 , obtained from the soil bacterium Streptomyces kanamyceticus.
An aminoglycoside antibiotic marketed under the trade name Kantrex.
antibiotic (trade name Kantrex) used to treat severe infections

kanara.explanation: a historical region of southwestern India on the west coast

kanari.explanation: The oil-producing Java almond, Canarium commune. See Canarium .

kanawha.explanation: The Kanawha River, a tributary of the Ohio River.
a tributary of the Ohio River in West Virginia

kanchil.explanation: A small deer of the genus Tragulus , found in Java; a pygmy deer, deerlet, or chevrotain, as Tragulus pygmæus T.kanchil. See Tragulus .
A small chevrotain of the genus Tragulus, esp. Tragulus pygmæus , or Tragulus kanchil , inhabiting Java, Sumatra, and adjacent islands; a deerlet. It is noted for its agility and cunning.
A small, agile chevrotain of the genus Tragulus.

kand.explanation: Fluor spar; -- so called by Cornish miners.

kande.explanation: A measure of capacity used in Denmark and Norway, equal to 4.1 United States pints or 3.4 imperial pints.

kandelia.explanation: A genus of tropical East Indian trees belonging to the order Rhizophoraceæ , or mangrove family, differing botanically from Rhizophora , the mangrove, in its 5- to 6-parted calyx, lacerated petals, and 1-celled, 6-ovuled ovary.

kang.explanation: A large glazed earthenware jar, containing from 60 to 100 gallons, used in China for storing water.

A kind of ovenlike erection built of bricks, used in the northern provinces of China and in Manchuria as a bed, fire being placed underneath it in winter. Kangs are about three feet high, and vary in size; some of those provided in inns and hostelries afford sleeping-accommodation for many persons.

kanga.explanation: A garment worn by women in East Africa
A comb , required to be worn at all times by Sikhs , one of the five Ks .

kangaroo.explanation: Any of various large herbivorous marsupials of the family Macropodidae of Australia and adjacent islands, having short forelimbs, large hind limbs used for leaping, and a long tapered tail.

An early form of ‘safety’ bicycle which had a large wheel in front and a small one in the rear, the forks being connected by a curved backbone, as in the ordinary ‘high’ bicycle, but with the saddle back of the large wheel.
plural In stock-exchange slang, West Australian mining shares.
A large marsupial mammal of Australia, Macropus giganteus ; by extension, any herbivorous and saltatorial marsupial of the family Macropodidæ (which see for technical characters).

Any one of numerous species of jumping marsupials of the family Macropodidæ . They inhabit Australia, New Guinea, and adjacent islands, They have long and strong hind legs and a large tail, while the fore legs are comparatively short and feeble. The giant kangaroo ( Macropus major ) is the largest species, sometimes becoming twelve or fourteen feet in total length. The tree kangaroos, belonging to the genus Dendrolagus, live in trees; the rock kangaroos, of the genus Petrogale, inhabit rocky situations; and the brush kangaroos, of the genus Halmaturus, inhabit wooded districts. See wallaby .
the edible fruit of the Tasmanian plant Solanum aviculare .
a perennial Australian forage grass ( Anthistiria australis ).
the jerboa kangaroo. See under Jerboa .
A member of a family of large marsupials with strong hind legs for hopping , mainly found in Australia, scientific name macropod .
A hooded jacket with a front pocket , usually of fleece material, a kangaroo jacket.
To practice kangaroo care on an infant; to hold a premature infant against the skin.
any of several herbivorous leaping marsupials of Australia and New Guinea having large powerful hind legs and a long thick tail

kangaroolike.explanation: Resembling or characteristic of a kangaroo .

kangri.explanation: A small wicker-covered clay pot containing hot coals, worn under clothing in Kashmir to warm the skin.

kanji.explanation: A Japanese system of writing based on borrowed or modified Chinese characters.
A character used in this system of writing.
Chinese characters as used for the Japanese language.

kannume.explanation: A fish, Mormyrus kannume , of the family Mormyridæ , found in the Nile. It was an object of veneration to the ancient Egyptians.

kanoon.explanation: A Near Eastern and Caucasian musical instrument related to the zither , dulcimer , harp , or sackbut having either 26 strings and a single bridge , or twice that number and two bridges.

kantar.explanation: a unit of weight used in Eastern Mediterranean countries, varying from place to place (44,93kg in Egypt)

kantele.explanation: A stringed instrument of the zither family, used in the traditional music of Finland.
A traditional plucked string instrument of the zither family.

kanten.explanation: A kind of gelose or gelatin, sometimes called Japanese isinglass , prepared in Japan from several species of seaweed, particularly from the cartilaginous Florideœ , and used for soups, as well as in the trades, as, for example, in dressing woven goods. It is usually sold in irregular prismatic sticks, resembling glue.

kantianism.explanation: The doctrine of the German philosopher Immanuel Kant (1724-1804), one of the most influential of metaphysicians.
The doctrine or theory of Kant; the Kantian philosophy.

kantist.explanation: A disciple or follower of Kant.
A disciple or follower of Kant.

kanuka.explanation: Kunzea ericoides, the white tea tree of Australia and New Zealand , which can grow at high altitudes and in close proximity to geothermal features such as fumaroles .

kanzu.explanation: A long, usually white garment worn by men in Africa.
(Swahili) a long garment (usually white) with long sleeves; worn by men in East Africa

kaoliang.explanation: Tall millet; the name in China of Sorghum vulgare or Indian millet.
A distilled alcoholic drink made from sorghum .
sorghums of China and Manchuria having small white or brown grains (used for food) and dry pithy stalks (used for fodder, fuel and thatching)

kaolin.explanation: A fine clay used in ceramics and refractories, as a filler or coating for paper and textiles, as an additive in food and toothpaste, and as an antidiarrheal drug.
A fine variety of clay, resulting from the decomposition of feldspar.

A very pure white clay, ordinarily in the form of an impalpable powder, and used to form the paste of porcelain; China clay; porcelain clay. It is chiefly derived from the decomposition of common feldspar.
A fine clay , rich in kaolinite , used in ceramics , paper - making , etc.
a fine usually white clay formed by the weathering of aluminous minerals (as feldspar); used in ceramics and as an absorbent and as a filler (e.g., in paper)

kaoline.explanation: a fine usually white clay formed by the weathering of aluminous minerals (as feldspar); used in ceramics and as an absorbent and as a filler (e.g., in paper)

kaolinised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kaolinise .

kaolinite.explanation: A mineral, Al 2 Si 2 O 5 (OH) 4 , that is the principal constituent of kaolin.
A common hydrous aluminosilicate mineral found in sediments , soils and sedimentary rocks , Al 2 Si 2 O 5( OH )4; one of the kaolin group of minerals.
a mineral consisting of aluminum silicate; main source of kaolin

kaolinization.explanation: The process by which certain minerals, particularly common feldspar, have been altered into kaolin.
The process by which feldspar is changed into kaolin.
The act or process of kaolinizing .

kaolinized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kaolinize .

kaon.explanation: Any of a group of four mesons, one positively charged and one negatively charged, having a mass 966 times that of an electron, and two electrically neutral, having a mass 974 times that of an electron. The two charged kaons have the same mean lifetime, about 1.24 × 10 −10 second; the two neutral kaons have lifetimes of about 9 × 10 −11 second and 5 × 10 −8 second.
any of four unstable subatomic particles , mesons , they are a combination of a strange quark or antiquark and either an up or down quark or antiquark
an unstable meson produced as the result of a high-energy particle collision

kapa.explanation: In Hawaii, cloth of any kind; clothes generally.

kapelle.explanation: In Germany, a musical establishment consisting of a band or orchestra, with or without a choir, under the direction and training of a kapellmeister.
A chapel; hence, the choir or orchestra of a prince's chapel; now, a musical establishment, usually orchestral.

kapellmeister.explanation: A leader or conductor of a musical group such as an orchestra .
A term used during the baroque and classical period for the person in charge of music at a noble court .

kaph.explanation: The 11th letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
The eleventh letter (ℶ) of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding to the Greek kappa and English k or c. Its numerical value is XX.
The eleventh letter of many Semitic alphabets/abjads ( Phoenician , Aramaic , Hebrew , Syriac , Arabic and others).
the 11th letter of the Hebrew alphabet

kapok.explanation: A silky fiber obtained from the pods of the kapok tree, used for insulation and as padding in pillows, mattresses, and life preservers.
The silky wool which invests the seeds of Eriodendron anfractuosum , a species of silk-cotton tree botanically related to the cotton-plants, found in the East and the West Indies.
A silky wool derived from the seeds of Ceiba pentandra (syn. Eriodendron anfractuosum ), a bombaceous tree of the East and West Indies.
A silky fibre obtained from the silk-cotton tree used for insulation and stuffing for pillows, mattresses, etc.
a plant fiber from the kapok tree; used for stuffing and insulation
massive tropical tree with deep ridges on its massive trunk and bearing large pods of seeds covered with silky floss; source of the silky kapok fiber

kapp.explanation: In electricity , an obsolete practical unit for magnetic flux, equal to 6,000 maxwells or c. g. s. units.

kappa.explanation: The tenth letter of the Greek alphabet.
The Greek letter K : represented in English by k , and sometimes by c.
The Greek letter κ: represented in English by k , and sometimes by c.
The tenth letter of the Greek alphabet.
A tortoise -like creature in the Japanese mythology.
the 10th letter of the Greek alphabet

kapparah.explanation: A Jewish custom by which, on the eve of the Day of Atonement, a fowl (a cock for a man and a hen for a woman), alter several passages from the Scriptures treating of atonement, confession, and prayer have been repeated, is moved around the head three times.

kappland.explanation: A Swedish land-measure, equal to 437½ Swedish square ells, or 6.1 English square rods.

kapuka.explanation: small New Zealand broadleaf evergreen tree often cultivated in warm regions as an ornamental

kaput.explanation: Out of order ; not working ; broken .

karabiner.explanation: an oblong metal ring with a spring clip; used in mountaineering to attach a rope to a piton or to connect two ropes

karaism.explanation: The doctrines or tenets of the Karaites.

karaka.explanation: A New Zealand tree, Corynocarpus lævigata , of the cashew family, yielding orange-colored berries two or three inches long.

karakul.explanation: Any of a breed of Central Asian sheep having a wide tail and wool that is curled, glossy, and usually black in the young but brownish or grayish in adults.
The pelt of a newborn or sometimes fetal karakul lamb, used for clothing.
Wool from a karakul sheep, used for carpet yarn and felting.
A type of Astrakhan, esp. in fine grades, obtained from the Karakul sheep. See sense 2 and cf. caracul .

A hardy coarse-haired sheep of central Asia, bearing a soft curly fleece that is black in the young lambs, but which grows brown or gray when adult; the lambs are valued for their soft curly black fur.
A large lake in the Pamirs of Central Asia, lying 13,200 feet above sea level.
A Central Asian breed of sheep .
hardy coarse-haired sheep of central Asia; lambs are valued for their soft curly black fur

karamu.explanation: Any one of several species of Australasian trees and shrubs belonging to the genus Coprosma , especially C. lucida. See orangeleaf , coffee-bush , and Coprosma .

karaoke.explanation: A music entertainment system providing prerecorded accompaniment to popular songs that a performer sings live, usually by following the words on a video screen.

A form of entertainment popular in clubs , at parties , etc, in which individual members of the public sing along to pre-recorded instrumental versions of popular songs, the lyrics of which are displayed for the singer on a screen in time with the music .
singing popular songs accompanied by a recording of an orchestra (usually in bars or nightclubs)

karat.explanation: A unit of measure for the fineness of gold, equal to 1 / 24 part. Pure gold is 24 karat; gold that is 50 percent pure is 12 karat.
the unit of measurement for the proportion of gold in an alloy; 18-karat gold is 75 2.122e-314old; 24-karat gold is pure gold.
A unit of fineness or concentration of gold equalling 1/24 part of gold in an alloy .
the unit of measurement for the proportion of gold in an alloy; 18-karat gold is 75% gold; 24-karat gold is pure gold

karatas.explanation: Nidularium karatas, a West Indian plant of the pineapple family.

karate.explanation: A Japanese martial art in which sharp blows and kicks are administered to pressure-sensitive points on the body of an opponent.
a traditional Japanese system of unarmed combat; sharp blows and kicks are given to pressure-sensitive points on the body of the opponent.
An Okinawan martial art involving primarily punching and kicking , but additionally, advanced throws, arm bars, grappling and all means of fighting.
a traditional Japanese system of unarmed combat; sharp blows and kicks are given to pressure-sensitive points on the body of the opponent

karbi.explanation: A small stingless bee, probably Melipona carbonaria , about of an inch in length, which builds its comb in the shape of a spiral staircase. It fights desperately with its mandibles and is apparently of a very fierce disposition.

kareau.explanation: In New Zealand, Ripogonum scandens , a climbing shrub of the smilax family, the slender wiry stems of which form interwoven thickets in the forest. The long underground root-stocks of this plant have been used as sarsaparilla by the settlers, and the stems as cord and for weaving baskets. Also called pirita .

karela.explanation: Momordica charantia, the bitter melon or bitter gourd.

karinghota.explanation: A small tree, Samandura ( Samadera ) Indica , of the Simarubaceœ found in Hindustan and Ceylon. Its bark yields a tonic and febrifuge, and its seed an oil used for rheumatism. Its wood is light, but durable.

karite.explanation: A sapo-taceous tree, Butyrospermum ( Bassia ) Parkii , abounding in central Africa.

karma.explanation: The totality of a person's actions and conduct during successive incarnations, regarded as causally influencing his or her destiny.
The law or principle through which such influence is believed to operate.
Fate or destiny resulting from one's previous actions.
A distinctive aura, atmosphere, or feeling.

In Hindu religion , one's action or acts considered as determining his lot after death and in a following existence; the aggregate of merits and demerits of a sentient being in one of his successive existences.

In theosophy : The doctrine of fate, destiny, or necessity as an invariable sequence of cause and effect; the theory of inevitable consequence, In the concrete, the result of one's actions; that which happens to one for better or worse, in matters over which one may exercise any choice or volition.
One's acts considered as fixing one's lot in the future existence.

The doctrine of fate as the inflexible result of cause and effect, especially the principle by which a person is rewarded or punished in a subsequent incarnation for deeds in the previous incarnation; the theory of inevitable consequence.
The supposed non-physical emanations that a person gives off, which may affect other people; vibrations.

The concept of "action" or "deed" in Indian and Nepalese religions understood as that which causes the entire cycle of cause and effect (i.e., the cycle called samsara ) described in the dharmic traditions, namely: Hindu , Jain , Sikh and Buddhist philosophies. The total effect of a person's actions and conduct during the successive phases of his existence , regarded as determining his next incarnation .
A distinctive feeling , aura , or atmosphere .
The idea that one reaps what one sows; destiny; fate.
(Hinduism and Buddhism) the effects of a person's actions that determine his destiny in his next incarnation

karmathian.explanation: One of a Mohammedan sect which arose in Turkey about the end of the ninth century.
One of a Mohammedan sect founded in the ninth century by Karmat.

karn.explanation: In Corn. mining , a pile or heap of rocks; sometimes, the solid rock.
A pile of rocks; sometimes, the solid rock. See cairn .

karoo.explanation: An arid plateau of southern Africa.
Any vast prairie bordering a desert .

kaross.explanation: A dressed animal skin, or several skins sewed together, used in southern Africa as a cloak, rug, or blanket.
A garment of fur worn by the natives of South Africa. Also spelled carosse .
A native garment or rug of skin sewed together in the form of a square.
A treated animal-skin cloak with the hair still left on.
A blanket of treated animal-skin with the hair left on.

karree.explanation: A plant root which produces honey beer when powdered and fermented.

karri.explanation: In Western Australia, a gigantic tree, Eucalyptus diversicolor.
The tree Eucalyptus diversicolor, native to south-western Western Australia
The hard timber from the karri tree.

karroo.explanation: One of the dry table-lands of South Africa, which often rise terracelike to considerable elevations.
a vast plateau, in Cape Colony, stretching through five degrees of longitude, at an elevation of about 3,000 feet.

karst.explanation: An area of irregular limestone in which erosion has produced fissures, sinkholes, underground streams, and caverns.
A type of land formation , usually with many caves formed through the dissolving of limestone by underground drainage .

kart.explanation: A miniature car used in racing.

kartel.explanation: A wooden hammock used in an ox-wagon.

karting.explanation: An open-wheeled motor sport that uses small vehicles called karts or go-karts .

karyaster.explanation: In cytology , the star-shaped cluster of chromosomes in the karyokinetic spindle: opposed to cytaster . See aster , 7, with cut.

karyochrome.explanation: In neurology , a name given by Nissl to certain nerve-cells in which the cell-body is very small but in which the nucleus is as large as in ordinary nerve-cells or at any rate larger than that of a neuroglia cell. See caryochrome .
A type of neuron that has a nucleus that stains intensely

karyocyte.explanation: Any cell that has a nucleus

karyogamy.explanation: The coming together and fusing of cell nuclei, as in fertilization.
In embryology , the union of two nuclei, as during the fertilization of the egg by the spermatozoön.
The fusion of two nuclei within a cell, especially as the second stage of syngamy .

karyokinesis.explanation: In embryology , the series of active changes which take place in the nucleus of a living cell in the process of division. Also written caryocinesis .

The indirect division of cells in which, prior to division of the cell protoplasm, complicated changes take place in the nucleus, attended with movement of the nuclear fibrils; -- opposed to karyostenosis . The nucleus becomes enlarged and convoluted, and finally the threads are separated into two groups which ultimately become disconnected and constitute the daughter nuclei . Called also mitosis . See Cell development, under cell .
The changes that occur in the nucleus of a cell, especially movements of the chromosomes, in the process of cell division.
The process of change that takes place during the division of a cell nucleus at mitosis or meiosis .
organic process consisting of the division of the nucleus of a cell during mitosis or meiosis

karyokinetic.explanation: of or relating to the division of the nucleus of a cell during mitosis or meiosis

karyologically.explanation: By means of, or with reference to, karyology

karyology.explanation: The study of the nuclei of cells , especially with regard to the chromosomes which they contain.
The characteristics of a particular cellular nucleus or group of nuclei, or of the chromosomes therein.

karyolymph.explanation: The colorless, liquid component of the cell nucleus.
The liquid contents of the cell-nucleus, as distinguished from the less liquid or more stable linin reticulum, chromosomes, and nucleoli. Also called karyenchyma .
The liquid part of the nucleus of a cell
a clear liquid in the cell nucleus in which the nucleolus and chromatin and other structures are dispersed

karyolysis.explanation: The dissolution of the nucleus of a cell by the action of deoxyribonuclease
disintegration and dissolution of a cell nucleus when a cell dies

karyomere.explanation: A saclike vesicle containing a small portion of the nuclear material after atypical mitosis

karyomicrosome.explanation: One of the minute granules or microsomes supposed to constitute the karyoplasm of the cell, as the cytomicrosomes are supposed to make up the cytoplasm.

karyomitome.explanation: In cytology , the fibrillar net or reticulum which extends through the nucleus of the cell in the resting-stage.

karyomiton.explanation: The reticular network of fine fibers, of which the nucleus of a cell is in part composed; -- in opposition to kytomiton , or the network in the body of the cell.

karyomitosis.explanation: In biology , the splitting of the chromatin fibers of a nucleus; also, a figure resulting from such splitting.

karyon.explanation: a part of the cell containing DNA and RNA and responsible for growth and reproduction

karyoplasm.explanation: The substance of which the more definitely formed portions of the nucleus of a cell, including the nuclear wall, the nucleoli, and the intranucleolar network, are composed. The remaining substance of the cell is called the nuclear matrix or nuclear fluid. Also called nucleoplasm .
The protoplasmic substance of the nucleus of a cell; nucleoplasm; -- in opposition to cytoplasm , the protoplasm of the cell.
the protoplasm that constitutes the nucleus of a cell

karyorrhexis.explanation: The destructive fragmentation of the nucleus of a dying cell whereby its chromatin is distributed irregularly throughout the cytoplasm

karyosome.explanation: An irregular aggregation of chromatin in the nucleus of a cell not undergoing mitosis.
A nucleolus-like mass of chromatin in the cell-nucleus: distinguished from the plasmosome , or true nucleolus.

karyotype.explanation: The characterization of the chromosomal complement of an individual or a species, including number, form, and size of the chromosomes.
A photomicrograph of chromosomes arranged according to a standard classification.
To classify and array (the chromosome complement of an organism or a species) according to the arrangement, number, size, shape, or other characteristics of the chromosomes.
The observed characteristics (number, type, shape etc) of the chromosomes of an individual or species .
A record of such characteristics, usually photographic .
( genetics ) A group of individuals or species that have the same chromosomal characteristics.
To investigate or record such characteristics
the appearance of the chromosomal makeup of a somatic cell in an individual or species (including the number and arrangement and size and structure of the chromosomes)

kasha.explanation: A porridge made from boiled buckwheat groats , or sometimes from other cereal groats .

kashim.explanation: A traditional, large, semisubterranean men's communal house, in which communal and ceremonial events are hosted.

kashrut.explanation: The body of Jewish dietary law.
The Jewish dietary laws , stating which foods are fit to eat ( kosher ).

kasolite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing hydrogen , lead , oxygen , silicon , and uranium .

kassite.explanation: A rare mineral that is a basic oxide of calcium and titanium , with the chemical formula Ca Ti 2 O 4(O H )2.
an ancient language spoken by the Kassites
a member of an ancient people who ruled Babylonia between 1600 and 1200 BC

kassu.explanation: A kind of catechu made from the fruit of the betelnut-palm, Areca Catechu , serving in India the same purposes as the true catechu.

kat.explanation: The principal ancient Egyptian unit of weight, equal almost to one fiftieth of a pound avoirdupois, according to several well-preserved standards. Also ket .
An Arabian shrub ( Catha edulis ) the leaves of which are used as tea by the Arabs.
Symbol for katal , an SI unit of measurement of catalytic activity .
the leaves of the shrub Catha edulis which are chewed like tobacco or used to make tea; has the effect of a euphoric stimulant

katabasis.explanation: A journey downwards : a journey downhill , a decrease of winds, a military retreat , a trip to the underworld ; a trip from the interior of a country to the coast.

katabatic.explanation: Of or relating to the downward flow of cold dense air.
of an air current or wind; moving downward or down a slope because of cooling especially at night

katabolic.explanation: Of or pertaining to catabolism; same as catabolic .
relating to or characterized by catabolism

katabolism.explanation: Destructive or downward metabolism; regressive metamorphism; same as catabolism (now the more common spelling); -- opposed to anabolism . See disassimilation .
breakdown in living organisms of more complex substances into simpler ones together with release of energy

katakana.explanation: A relatively angular kana used especially to write foreign words, onomatopoetic words, and the names of plants and animals in Japanese.
One of the two styles of writing the syllabary of 48 letters in use among the Japanese, the other being hiragana.
A Japanese syllabary used when writing words borrowed from foreign languages other than Chinese, specific names of plants and animals and other jargon, or to emphasize a word or phrase.

katamorphism.explanation: In geology , any change in the texture of rocks produced by fracturing and granulation, with recrystallization, whereby rocks become finer-grained and foliated, as the production of gneisses and schists from granites. Chamberlin and Salisbury , 1904.
Any form of metamorphism that occurs near the Earth's surface
metamorphism that occurs at or near the earth's surface; breaks down complex minerals into simpler ones

katana.explanation: A Japanese sword which, in its modern form, has a single edge and is slightly curved toward the point.
A type of Japanese longsword , 日本刀 (にほんとう, nihontō) having a single edge and slight curvature.

katar.explanation: an Arab country on the peninsula of Qatar; achieved independence from the United Kingdom in 1971; the economy is dominated by oil
a peninsula extending northward from the Arabian mainland into the Persian Gulf

katastate.explanation: A substance formed by a catabolic process; -- opposed to anastate . See catabolic .

katatonia.explanation: A form of insanity characterized by periods of acute mania and melancholia, and by cataleptoid and epileptoid states.

katcina.explanation: Among the Hopi, a supernatural being regarded as a clan ancestor, and impersonated in certain ceremonials by masked men wearing totemic designs characteristic of the clan.
A masked man who impersonates the clan ancestor.
A figure or image made in imitation of one of the masked impersonators.

kathak.explanation: One of the 8 classical dance forms of India.

katharometer.explanation: A device used for analyzing gas mixtures by measuring their thermal conductivity .

katharsis.explanation: purging of emotional tensions; -- usually spelled catharsis .
purging the body by the use of a cathartic to stimulate evacuation of the bowels

kathenotheism.explanation: Belief that multiple deities exist, and different deities are supreme among them at different times.

kathodic.explanation: botany , turned away from the direction in which the genetic spiral runs: said of that half of a leaf which has this characteristic. The opposite half is anodic. Göbel.

katipo.explanation: A venomous spider of the family Theridiidœ the Latrodectus katipo , of a black color with a marked red spot, found in New Zealand usually among the rushes and sedges near the sea-shore. The bite of this spider is dangerous and sometimes fatal.
A venomous spider , Latrodectus katipo, endemic to New Zealand .

katipunan.explanation: Among the Filipinos, a secret society: sometimes one formed for a political purpose.

katmon.explanation: A handsome evergreen tree, Dillenia Philippensis , with large, coriaceous, sharply serrate leaves, and fine large flowers composed of an imbricating calyx, five white petals, and numerous yellow stamens arranged in two series so as to form two cup-shaped masses.

katsuwonidae.explanation: A natural family of fish which in some classifications is considered a separate family comprising the oceanic bonitos.
in some classifications considered a separate family comprising the oceanic bonitos

katun.explanation: In the ancient calendar of the Maya Indians, a period of twenty years.

katurai.explanation: In Guam and the Philippine Islands, Agati grandiflora , a small tree of the bean family, of East Indian origin, having pinnate leaves, large papilionaceous flowers, and long, slender, sickle-shaped pods.

katydid.explanation: Any of various orthopteran insects of the family Tettigoniidae, having long antennae and usually a green body, the male of which produces a shrill sound by rubbing together specialized organs on the forewings.
An orthopterousinsect of the family Locustidœ of large size, green color, and arboreal habits.

A large, green, arboreal, orthopterous insect ( Cyrtophyllus concavus ) of the family Locustidæ , common in the United States. The males have stridulating organs at the bases of the front wings. During the summer and autumn, in the evening, the males make a peculiar, loud, shrill sound, resembling the combination Katy-did , whence the name.
A type of grasshopper , scientific name Tettigoniidae.
large green long-horned grasshopper of North America; males produce shrill sounds by rubbing together special organs on the forewings

katzenjammer.explanation: A state of depression or bewilderment.
loud confused noise from many sources
disagreeable aftereffects from the use of drugs (especially alcohol)

kauri.explanation: Any of several coniferous evergreen trees of the genus Agathis, especially A. australis of New Zealand, having broad leathery leaves.
The white close-grained wood of one of these trees.
A resinous copal or a fossilized resin of these trees, chiefly A. australis, formerly used in varnishes and in the manufacture of linoleum.
A tall coniferous tree of New Zealand Agathis australis , or Dammara australis ), having white straight-grained wood furnishing valuable timber and also yielding one kind of dammar resin.
any of various species of Dammara.
A large conifer of the family Araucariaceae.
resin of the kauri trees of New Zealand; found usually as a fossil; also collected for making varnishes and linoleum
