any of several large brown seaweeds (order Laminariales).
large brown seaweeds having fluted leathery fronds

kelper.explanation: A Falkland Islander , native to the Falkland Islands .

kelpfish.explanation: A name applied to a number of other, unrelated fishes living among the kelp, as rock-fish is applied to those living in rocky places.
A labroid fish, Platyglossus semicinctus , with 9 dorsal spines, and of a greenish-brown color with bright reflections. It is common southward along the Lower Californian coast.
Any fish of the family Ditremidæ , found on the west coast of the United States.
A small California food fish ( Heterostichus rostratus ), living among kelp. The name is also applied to species of the genus Platyglossus.
A perciform fish in the family Chironemidae, native to coastal Australia and New Zealand .

kelpie.explanation: An imaginary spirit of the waters, generally appearing in the form of a horse, who was believed to give warning of approaching death by drowning, and sometimes maliciously to assist in drowning persons.
An imaginary spirit of the waters, horselike in form, vulgarly believed to warn, by preternatural noises and lights, those who are to be drowned.
A malevolent shapeshifting spirit, most often in the form of a horse, believed to haunt the rivers and lochs of Scotland.
(Scottish folklore) water spirit in the form of a horse that likes to drown its riders
an Australian sheepdog with pointed ears

kelpware.explanation: The bladder-wrack or black tang, Fucus vesiculosus.

kelpwort.explanation: The prickly glasswort, Salsola Kali , burned to produce barilla, a substance resembling kelp. See kelp , 2.
bushy plant of Old World salt marshes and sea beaches having prickly leaves; burned to produce a crude soda ash

kelpy.explanation: (Scottish folklore) water spirit in the form of a horse that likes to drown its riders

kelt.explanation: A thin , recently spawned Atlantic salmon .

kelter.explanation: Alternative spelling of kilter . meaning order or balance

keltie.explanation: A large glass or bumper, imposed as a fine on those who, as it is expressed, do not drink fair.

kelvin.explanation: A unit of absolute temperature equal to 1/273.16 of the absolute temperature of the triple point of water. One kelvin degree is equal to one Celsius degree.
A temperature scale in which zero occurs at absolute zero and each degree equals one kelvin. Water freezes at 273.15 K and boils at 373.15 K.
A name proposed, in honor of Lord Kelvin, for the kilowatt-hour which is the British Board of Trade unit of work.

The SI unit of temperature, defined as being 1/273.16 of the triple point of water; abbreviated K. The melting point of water at 760 mm pressure is 273.15 Kelvins, and the boiling point 373.15 Kelvins. One degree Kelvin is equal to one degree Centigrade, and 9/5 degrees Fahrenheit.
In the International System of Units , the base unit of thermodynamic temperature ; 1/273.16 of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water . Shown as "K".
A unit interval on the Kelvin scale .
A unit for a specific temperature on the Kelvin scale .
the basic unit of thermodynamic temperature adopted under the Systeme International d'Unites
British physicist who invented the Kelvin scale of temperature and pioneered undersea telegraphy (1824-1907)

kelyphite.explanation: An alteration-product forming a zone about crystals of pyrope, found in Bohemia. It nearly resembles serpentine in composition.
A substitution mineral found surrounding garnet in peridotites .

kemp.explanation: The act of striving for superiority in any way.
Coarse hair which is closely mingled with the finer hair or wool, and has to be separated from it before the manufacturing of fine goods, especially in goat's hair of choice and expensive kind.
The ribwort-plantain, Plantago lanceolata , more especially the stalk and spike; also, the common plantain, Plantago major , and perhaps P. media
Coarse, rough hair in wool or fur, injuring its quality.
Coarse, rough hair , wool , or fur ; (in the plural) knotty hairs that will not felt .

kempite.explanation: An orthorhombic-dipyramidal emerald green mineral containing chlorine , hydrogen , manganese , and oxygen .

kemple.explanation: A Scottish weight of straw, from 14 to 16 stone tron.

kemps.explanation: The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain ( Plantago Lanceolata ).

kempt.explanation: neat and tidy ; especially used of hair

ken.explanation: To have knowledge or an understanding.
Cognizance; physical or intellectual view; especially, reach of sight or knowledge.

Scots law , to acknowledge or recognize by a judicial act: as, to ken a widow to her terce (that is, to recognize or decree by a judicial act the right of a widow to the life-rent of her share of her deceased husband's lands). See terce .
A place where low or disreputable characters lodge or meet: as, a padding- ken (a lodging-house for tramps); a sport ing- ken
A prefecture or territorial division of Japan, governed by a kenrei. Japan is now divided into 3 fu and about 40 ken.
A Japanese measure of length, equal to 71½ English inches.
A house; esp., one which is a resort for thieves.
Cognizance; view; especially, reach of sight or knowledge.
To know; to understand; to take cognizance of.
To recognize; to descry; to discern.
To discover by sight ; to catch sight of ; to descry .
range of what one can know or understand

kenaf.explanation: Hibiscus cannabinus, an annual or biennial herbaceous plant found mainly in Asia .
The fibre obtained from this plant, similar to jute .
fiber from an East Indian plant Hibiscus cannabinus
valuable fiber plant of East Indies now widespread in cultivation

kench.explanation: A box or bin for use in salting fish or skins.

kendir.explanation: A plant of the dogbane family, Apocynum venetian , which yields a strong fiber, used by the natives of Turkestan for fishinglines, rope, and twine.

kendo.explanation: The Japanese martial art of fencing with bamboo swords.
a Japanese martial art using " swords " of split bamboo .

kennebunker.explanation: A valise for clothes which Maine lumbermen take with them into the wood (‘up the Kennebunk’ and other rivers). A variant form, Kennebecker , assumes an origin in the Kennebec river.

kenned.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ken .

kennedya.explanation: A genus of perennial leguminous herbs, belonging to the tribe Phaseoleæ , or bean family, most nearly related to Hardenbergia , but differing from it in the more showy red or purple flowers and longer keel (relatively to the wings).
genus of Australian woody vines having showy red or purplish flowers

kennel.explanation: A house or cot for a dog, or for a pack of hounds.
A pack of hounds; a collection of dogs of any breed or of different breeds.
The hole of a fox or other beast; a haunt.
A little canal or channel; specifically, the drainage-channel of a street; a gutter.
A head-dress worn by women in the reign of Henry VIII.
The water course of a street; a little canal or channel; a gutter; also, a puddle.
To put or keep in a kennel.
A house for a dog or for dogs, or for a pack of hounds.
A pack of hounds, or a collection of dogs.
The hole of a fox or other beast; a haunt.
To lie or lodge; to dwell, as a dog or a fox.
A gutter at the edge of a street.
A house or shelter for a dog .
A facility at which dogs are reared or boarded.
The dogs kept at such a facility; a pack of hounds.
To house or board a dog (or less commonly another animal).
outbuilding that serves as a shelter for a dog

kenneled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kennel .

kennelled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kennel .

kennet.explanation: An old fabric of coarse texture; a kind of gray cloth.
A small dog of some particular breed.

kenning.explanation: A figurative, usually compound expression used in place of a name or noun, especially in Old English and Old Norse poetry; for example, storm of swords is a kenning for battle.
The cicatricula or tread of an egg. Also kinning .
In Old Norse, Anglo-Saxon, and other old Teutonic poetry, a distinctive poetical name, usually periphrastic in form, used in addition to, or substituted for, the usual name of a thing or person.
Sight; view; especially, a distant view at sea.
Range or extent of vision, especially at sea; hence, a marine measure of about twenty miles.
As little as one can recognize or discriminate; a small portion; a little: as, put in a kenning of salt.
The limit of vision at sea, being a distance of about twenty miles.
The tread of an egg; cicatricula .

A metaphorical phrase used in Germanic poetry (especially Old English or Old Norse) whereby a simple thing is described in an allusive way, such as ‘whale road’ for ‘sea’, or ‘enemy of the mast’ for ‘wind’.
Sight ; view ; a distant view at sea.
Range or extent of vision , especially at sea; (by extension) a marine measure of approximately twenty miles.
As little as one can recognise or discriminate ; a small portion ; a little.
conventional metaphoric name for something, used especially in Old English and Old Norse poetry

keno.explanation: A game of chance, similar to lotto, that uses balls rather than counters.
A game of chance depending on the drawing of numbers.
A gambling game, a variety of the game of lotto, played with balls or knobs, numbered, and cards also numbered.
A gambling game, a variety of the game of lotto, played with balls or knobs, numbered, and cards also numbered.
a game in which numbered balls are drawn at random and players cover the corresponding numbers on their cards

kenogenesis.explanation: Vitiated evolution, as distinguished from hereditary evolution; ontogenesis modified by adaptation, and therefore not true to its type; that development of an individual germ which does not truly epitomize and repeat the phylogenetic evolution of its race or stock: the opposite of palingenesis . See biogeny . Also kenogeny .

Modified evolution, in which nonprimitive characters make their appearance in consequence of a secondary adaptation of the embryo to the peculiar conditions of its environment; -- distinguished from palingenesis .

introduction during embryonic development of characters or structure not present in the earlier evolutionary history of the strain or species (such as the addition of the placenta in mammalian evolution)

kenophobia.explanation: An abnormal fear of empty spaces

kenosis.explanation: The relinquishment of some of the attributes of God by Jesus in becoming man and suffering death.
In theology , the self-limitation and self-renunciation of the Son of God in the incarnation.
Christ 's voluntary divestment of his divine powers.

kenoticism.explanation: The doctrine of the kenosis of Christ, that is, of the limitations implied in the incarnation. See kenosis .

kenoticist.explanation: One who believes in the theory of the kenosis.

kens.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of ken .

kenspeckle.explanation: kenspeck , and the more common form.
Having so marked an appearance as easily to be recognized.

kent.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of ken .

kentallenite.explanation: In petrography , a phanerocrys-talline rock composed of orthoclase and lime-soda-feldspar in nearly equal proportions, together with augite, biotite, and olivin; an olivin-monzomte.

kente.explanation: A brightly patterned, handwoven ceremonial cloth of the Ashanti.
A durable machine-woven fabric similar to this fabric, prominently featured in Afrocentric fashion.
A type of fabric made of interwoven cloth strips , native to the country of Ghana .

kentia.explanation: A genus of feather-palms belonging to the tribe Areceæ , formerly including a number of the finest palms of that tribe which have latterly been referred to various other genera, as Areca, Hydriastele, Nengella, Hedyscepe, Rhopalostylis, Clinostigma , and Howea.

kenticism.explanation: An expression characteristic of the Kentish dialect.

kentledge.explanation: Pig iron used as permanent ballast.
Nautical , pig-iron laid in the hold of a ship for ballast. Also kintledge .
In the British service, condemned shot, shell, and similar unserviceable articles.
Pigs of iron used for ballast.
Weights (often scrap or pig iron) used as permanent ballast on ships.
A system of weights (usually concrete or cast-iron blocks) used for load-testing piled foundations.

kentrogon.explanation: In rhizocephalous crustaceans, a larval stage in which the parasite attaches itself to the host by an antenna, throws off its whole trunk, leaving only its head, and undergoes other modifications including the formation of a hollow arrow-like process or borer through which the parasite enters the body-cavity of the host.

kentrolite.explanation: A rare silicate of lead and manganese occurring in southern Chili in acutely terminated crystals, also in sheaf-like aggregates of a reddish-brown color.
An orthorhombic-dipyramidal mineral containing aluminum , iron , lead , magnesium , manganese , oxygen , silicon , and titanium .

kentuckian.explanation: A native or an inhabitant of Kentucky.
a native or resident of Kentucky

kenyte.explanation: In petrography , a volcanic rock resembling pantellerite but more basic.

kephalin.explanation: One of a group of phospholipids (nitrogenous phosphorized fatty substances), present in all living cells and particularly noticeable in nervous tissue. Same as cephalin , which see.

kephir.explanation: A kind of fermented milk in use among the inhabitants of the northern Caucasus, and corresponding as an article of diet and medicine to kumiss in the southeastern steppes of Russia.

kepi.explanation: A French military cap with a flat circular top and a visor.
A kind of cap first worn by French troops in Algeria, and since much worn by other French troops and in other countries, as well as in public schools and institutions, etc.

A military cap having a close-fitting band, a round flat top sloping toward the front, and a visor. As originally worn by the French in Algeria about 1830 it was tall and stiff with a straight visor. It is now lower, has a curved visor, and is frequently soft.
A cap with a flat circular top and a visor, particularly associated with French uniforms.
a cap with a flat circular top and a visor

keps.explanation: A variant of keeps . See keeps and cage-shuts.

kept.explanation: Preterit and past participle of keep.
Simple past tense and past participle of keep .
(especially of promises or contracts) not violated or disregarded

ker.explanation: A Middle English form of car .

An unstressed introductory syllable, perhaps better written ka - or ke -, used in some dialectal words, without meaning in itself but. serving to introduce an emphatic stress, as in kerslap, kerchunk, kerplunk, kerwhaek , etc. It probably originated in the involuntary utterance which often precedes a sudden physical effort, as in striking with an ax or hammer or paving-rammer.

kerana.explanation: A kind of long trumpet, used among the Persians.

keraphyllocele.explanation: A sharply defined horn tumor projecting from the inner surface of the wall of a horse's hoof and appearing at the plantar surface as a semicircular thickening of the white line.

kerasin.explanation: A nitrogenous substance free from phosphorus, supposed to be present in the brain; a body closely related to cerebrin.
A nitrogenous substance, free from phosphorus , supposed to be present in the brain , and closely related to cerebrin .

keratalgia.explanation: In pathology , pain in the cornea.

keratectasia.explanation: abnormal bulging of the cornea of the eye

keratectomy.explanation: Surgical removal of a part of the cornea.
An operation that removes part of the cornea , as in keratomileusis .

keratin.explanation: A tough, insoluble protein substance that is the chief structural constituent of hair, nails, horns, and hooves.

A sulfur-containing fibrous protein constituting the main structural protein of hard epidermal tissues, such as horn, hair, feathers, nails, claws, hoofs, and the like. It is an insoluble substance, and, unlike elastin, is not dissolved even by gastric or pancreatic juice. By decomposition with sulphuric acid it yields leucine and tyrosine plus various other acid-stable amino acids. The amino acid composition varies, but it usually has a high percentage of cystine, which stabilizes and insolubilizes the protein by forming intrachain linkages. A softer form of keratin is present in the epidermis and whalebone. Called also epidermose .
A protein which hair and nails are comprised of.
a fibrous scleroprotein that occurs in the outer layer of the skin and in horny tissues such as hair, feathers, nails, and hooves

keratinization.explanation: the process in which cells from beneath the skin are converted to hair and nails (made of keratin )
organic process by which keratin is deposited in cells and the cells become horny (as in nails and hair)

keratinize.explanation: To produce keratin or become like keratin.
To take on the appearance of keratin, or become impregnated with keratin
become horny and impregnated with keratin

keratinized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of keratinize .

keratinous.explanation: Consisting of, or made from keratin

keratitis.explanation: inflammation of the cornea causing watery painful eyes and blurred vision

keratocele.explanation: A herniation of Descemet's membrane in the eye .

keratoconjunctivitis.explanation: Inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva.
An inflammation of the cornea and the conjunctiva .
inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva

keratoconus.explanation: A degenerative non- inflammatory disorder of the eye in which structural changes within the cornea cause it to thin and change to a more conical shape than its normal even curve.
abnormal cone-shaped protrusion of the cornea of the eye; can be treated by epikeratophakia

keratoderma.explanation: any skin disorder consisting of a growth that appears horny

keratodermia.explanation: any skin disorder consisting of a growth that appears horny

keratoglobus.explanation: A disorder of the eye in which the cornea is enlarged and globular in shape

keratoiritis.explanation: inflammation of the cornea and the iris of the eye

keratolysis.explanation: The separation or loosening of the horny layer of the epidermis.
A skin disease characterized by a periodic shedding of the epidermis.
The removal of dead surface skin cells , used to treat various types of wart .
The periodic exfoliation of the epidermis

keratomalacia.explanation: An eye disorder that leads to a dry cornea , often caused by a deficiency of vitamin A .
softening and drying and ulceration of the cornea resulting from vitamin A deficiency; symptom of cystic fibrosis or sprue

keratome.explanation: An instrument for dividing the cornea in operations for cataract.
A surgical instrument for dividing the cornea in cataract operations .

keratonyxis.explanation: The operation of removing a cataract by thrusting a needle through the cornea of the eye, and breaking up the opaque mass.
The operation of removing a cataract by thrusting a needle through the cornea of the eye and breaking up the opaque mass .

keratophyre.explanation: In petrography , dense, compact porphyry, composed of alkali-feldspars and diopside. A variety containing quartz is called quartz-keratophyre .

keratoplasty.explanation: Surgery involving part or all of the cornea, especially corneal transplantation.
grafting or transplantation of the cornea
a surgical procedure in which part or all of a damaged or diseased cornea is replaced by healthy corneal tissue from a donor

keratoscope.explanation: A device for determining the presence of irregularities in the anterior surface of the cornea.
An ophthalmic instrument for assessing the shape of the anterior surface of the cornea .
medical instrument to examine the cornea in order to detect irregularities in its anterior surface

keratoscopy.explanation: In surgery , inspection of the cornea.
The measurement of the shape of the anterior surface of the cornea .
examination of the cornea with a keratoscope to detect irregularities in its anterior surface

keratose.explanation: A tough, horny animal substance entering into the composition of the skeleton of sponges, and other invertebrates; -- called also keratode .
Containing hornlike fibers or fibers of keratose; belonging to the Keratosa.
Relating to or marked by keratosis ; horny .

keratosis.explanation: Excessive growth of horny tissue of the skin.
In pathology , disease of the outer layers of the epidermis.
The condition of keratin growing on the skin.
a skin condition marked by an overgrowth of layers of horny skin

keratotomy.explanation: A surgical incision in the cornea .

keratto.explanation: The West Indian Agave Keratto (which see, under Agave ).

keraulophon.explanation: In organ-building , a stop having metal pipes of small scale, and a thin, somewhat reedy tone.

keraunograph.explanation: A figure or picture impressed by lightning upon the human body or elsewhere.
A figure or picture impressed by lightning upon the human body or elsewhere.

keraunophobia.explanation: An abnormal fear of thunder and lightning .

kerb.explanation: An irregular occasional spelling of curb , v., 4, and n. , 3.
The edge between the pavement and the roadway , consisting of a line of kerbstones .
To damage vehicle wheels or tyres by running into or over a pavement kerb.
an edge between a sidewalk and a roadway consisting of a line of curbstones (usually forming part of a gutter)

kerbed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kerb .

kerbstone.explanation: A paving stone that forms part of a kerb / curb
a paving stone forming part of a curb

kerchief.explanation: A square scarf, often worn as a head covering.

A head-dress composed of a simple square or oblong piece of linen, silk, or other material, worn folded, tied, pinned, or otherwise fastened about the head, or more or less loosely attached, so as to cover or drape the head and shoulders.
A similar square of linen, cotton, or silk, worn on or used about the person for other purposes than covering the head. Compare handkerchief, neckerchief , and napkin.
One who wears a kerchief; a woman.
A square of fine linen worn by women as a covering for the head; hence, anything similar in form or material, worn for ornament on other parts of the person; -- mostly used in compounds
A lady who wears a kerchief.
A piece of cloth used to cover the head.
a square scarf that is folded into a triangle and worn over the head or about the neck

kerchiefed.explanation: Dressed; hooded; covered; wearing a kerchief.

kerchunk.explanation: A sudden heavy blow or thump .
With a sudden heavy blow or thump.

kerf.explanation: A groove or notch made by a cutting tool, such as a saw or an ax.
The width of a groove made by a cutting tool.
A Middle English preterit of carve .
A cut; an incision; a stroke with a weapon.
A channel or cut made in wood by a saw or other cutting-instrument.
In a cloth-shearing machine, the wool taken off in one passage through the cutter.
A layer of hay or turf. [Prov. Eng.]—5. That which is cut; a Cutting.
A notch, channel, or slit made in any material by cutting or sawing.
The groove or slit created by cutting a workpiece; an incision .
The width of the groove made while cutting.
To cut a piece of wood or other material with several kerfs to allow it to be bent.

kerfed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kerf .

kerfing.explanation: A thin strip of wood kerfed to allow easy bending and then glued inside the body of a string instrument along the rim between its two abutting sides to reinforce the joint.

kerfuffle.explanation: A disorderly outburst , disturbance , commotion or tumult .

kerite.explanation: A kind of artificial vulcanite in which the caoutchouc is replaced by asphaltum or tar, combined with animal or vegetable oils.

A compound in which tar or asphaltum combined with animal or vegetable oils is vulcanized by sulphur, the product closely resembling rubber; -- used principally as an insulating material in telegraphy.
A compound in which tar or asphalt combined with animal or vegetable oils is vulcanized by sulphur , the product closely resembling rubber ; formerly used as an insulating material in telegraphy .

kermanji.explanation: The language of the Kurds; Kurdish.

kermes.explanation: A red dyestuff once prepared from the dried bodies of various female scale insects of the genus Kermes.
Short for kermes-mineral , or, more properly, mineral kermes.

A red dyestuff consisting of the dried bodies of the females of one or two species of Coccus , especially C. ilicis , an insect found on various species of oak in countries bordering on the Mediterranean.
[ capitalized ] [NL,] A genus of Coccinæ erected by Targioni-Tozzetti.

The dried bodies of the females of a scale insect ( Kermes ilices formerly Coccus ilicis ), allied to the cochineal insect, and found on several species of oak near the Mediterranean; also, the dye obtained from them. They are round, about the size of a pea, contain coloring matter analogous to carmine, and are used in dyeing. They were anciently thought to be of a vegetable nature, and were used in medicine.
A small European evergreen oak ( Quercus coccifera ) on which the kermes insect ( Kermes ilices , formerly Coccus ilicis ) feeds.
A genus of scale insects including many species that feed on oaks. The adult female resembles a small gall.
A compound of the trioxide and trisulphide of antimony, used in medicine. This substance occurs in nature as the mineral kermesite .
any of several insects of the genus Kermes
Crimson dye made from the crushed bodies of these insects

kermesite.explanation: Native oxysulphid of antimony, occurring in monoclinic crystals, or crystalline aggregates, of a cherry-red color. Also called antimonyblende and red antimony.
A triclinic-pinacoidal mineral containing antimony , oxygen , and sulfur .

kermess.explanation: In the Low Countries and in French Flanders, an annual fair and festival of a town or commune, characterized by feasting, dancing, grotesque processions, target-shooting, and other forms of amusement, which at one time reached a licentious extravagance.
A kind of entertainment, usually given for charitable purposes, in which the costumes and sports of the Flemish kermess are imitated.

kermis.explanation: An outdoor fair in the Low Countries.

kern.explanation: The portion of a typeface that projects beyond the body or shank of a character.
To provide (type) with a kern.
To adjust space between (characters) in typeset text.
A medieval Scottish or Irish foot soldier.
A loutish person.
churn .
type-founding , to form with a kern or projection, as-a type or letter.
A corn; grain; kernel.
In printing , that part of a type which projects beyond the body or shank, as in the Roman letters f and j as formerly made and some italic letters.
The last handful or sheaf of grain cut down at the close of the harvest. Also called kern-cut .
A harvest-home.
A dialectal form of quern .

In the ancient militia of Ireland and the Highlands of Scotland, a light-armed foot-soldier of the lowest and poorest grade, armed with a dart or skean: opposed to gallowglass , a heavy-armed soldier. The word is sometimes used in a collective sense.
Hence —2. An Irish churl or boor; by extension, any ignoble person; a drudge; a bumpkin.
In English law , an idle person or vagabond.
A part of the face of a type which projects beyond the body, or shank, such as in certain italic letters.
To form with a kern. See 2d kern .
A churn.
A hand mill. See quern .
Kernel; corn; grain.
The last handful or sheaf reaped at the harvest.
The harvest-home.
To harden, as corn in ripening.
To take the form of kernels; to granulate.
A light-armed foot soldier of the ancient militia of Ireland and Scotland; -- distinguished from gallowglass , and often used as a term of contempt.
Any kind of boor or low-lived person.
An idler; a vagabond.
A corn; grain; kernel.
A light-armed foot soldier of the ancient militia of Ireland and Scotland; in archaic contexts often used as a term of contempt.
Alternative form of quern .
any part of a letter which extends into the space used by another letter.
To adjust the horizontal space between selected pairs of letters (characters or glyphs ); to perform such adjustments to a portion of text, according to preset rules.
remove a portion of space between (adjacent letters)
the part of a metal typeface that projects beyond its body
furnish with a kern
United States composer of musical comedies (1885-1945)

kerned.explanation: Having part of the face projecting beyond the body or shank; -- said of type.
Having part of the face projecting beyond the body or shank ; -- said of type.
Simple past tense and past participle of kern .

kernel.explanation: A grain or seed, as of a cereal grass, enclosed in a husk.
The usually edible seed inside the hard covering of a nut or fruit stone.
The central or most important part; the core.
A small amount of something, especially when potentially developing into something else.
An enlarged lymphatic gland.
In metallurgy , a nucleus of a double sulphid of copper and iron obtained in roasting cupriferous iron pyrites. The kernels are separated by hand from the lumps of pyrites and are melted for copper.
The edible substance contained in the shell of a nut or the stone of a fruit.
Technically, in botany : In phanerogams, strictly, the whole body of a seed within the coats, namely, the embryo, and, when present, the albumen.
In pyrenomycetous fungi, in old usage, all of the soft parts of the pyrenocarp or perithecium within the firm outer wall. In both these senses a synonym of nucleus.
A gramineous seed with its husk or integument; a grain or corn: as, a kernel of wheat, oats, or maize: formerly applied also to the seed of the apple and other pulpy fruits.
The bundle of fat on the fore shoulder; any swelling or knob of flesh.
Figuratively — The central part of anything; a mass around which other matter is concreted; a nucleus in general.
The important part of anything, as a matter in discussion; the main or essential point, as opposed to matters of less import; the core; the gist: as, to come to the kernel of the question.
A battlement.
To harden or ripen into kernels; to produce kernels.

The essential part of a seed; all that is within the seed walls; the edible substance contained in the shell of a nut; hence, anything included in a shell, husk, or integument. See Illust. of endocarp .
A single seed or grain.
A small mass around which other matter is concreted; a nucleus; a concretion or hard lump in the flesh.
The central, substantial or essential part of anything; the gist; the core.
The core , center , or essence of an object or system.
The central (usually edible) part of a nut , especially once the hard shell has been removed.
A single seed or grain , especially of corn or wheat .
The stone of certain fruits, such as peaches or plums .
The central part of many computer operating systems which manages the system's resources and the communication between hardware and software components.
Those elements, in the domain of a function , which the function maps to zero .
The set of members of a fuzzy set that are fully included (i.e., whose grade of membership is 1).
the choicest or most essential or most vital part of some idea or experience
a single whole grain of a cereal
the inner and usually edible part of a seed or grain or nut or fruit stone

kernelly.explanation: Full of kernels; resembling kernels; of the nature of kernels.
Full of kernels ; resembling kernels; of the nature of kernels.

kernite.explanation: A colorless to white lustrous crystalline mineral, Na 2 B 4 O 7 · 4H 2 O, that is a major source of ore of boron.
A hydrated borate mineral , Na2B4O6(OH)2, originally discovered in the Mojave Desert.
a light soft mineral consisting of hydrated sodium borate in crystalline form; an important source of boron

kerns.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of kern .

kero.explanation: A stemless drinking cup, typically flaring outward toward the brim, traditionally used by the Inca and neighboring Andean peoples.
A type of wooden drinking vessel produced by the Incas .

kerogen.explanation: A fossilized material in shale and other sedimentary rock that yields oil upon heating.
any organic matter present in a sedimentary rock that is insoluble in organic solvents ; the precursor of oil and natural gas

kerolite.explanation: A metamorphic nickel -bearing phyllosilicate mineral similar to talc and serpentine .

kerosene.explanation: A thin oil distilled from petroleum or shale oil, used as a fuel for heating and cooking, in lamps, and as a denaturant for alcohol.
A mixture of liquid hydrocarbons distilled from petroleum, coal, bitumen, etc., extensively used as an illuminating fluid in all parts of the world.

An oil used for illuminating purposes, formerly obtained from the distillation of mineral wax, bituminous shale, etc., and hence called also coal oil . It is now produced in immense quantities, chiefly by the distillation and purification of petroleum. It consists chiefly of several hydrocarbons of the methane series, having from 10 to 16 carbon atoms in each molecule, and having a higher boiling point (175 - 325° C) than gasoline or the petroleum ethers, and a lower boling point than the oils.
A petroleum based thin and colorless fuel ; ( UK ) paraffin .
a flammable hydrocarbon oil used as fuel in lamps and heaters

kerosine.explanation: a flammable hydrocarbon oil used as fuel in lamps and heaters

kerplunk.explanation: To fall with a sound like that of a heavy object falling into water.

kerria.explanation: A genus of rosaceous plants of the tribe Spiræeæ , characterized by small, dry, cartilaginousand large, solitary, peduncled yellow-flowers terminating the branehlets.
Kerria japonica, the sole species in the genus Kerria, a deciduous shrub with five-petalled yellow flowers.

kerril.explanation: A venomous seasnake of the genus Hydrophis , as H. nigrocincta of Bengal.

kerrite.explanation: A kind of vermiculite from Franklin, North Carolina.

kers.explanation: A Middle English form of cress . See cress and curse .

kersantite.explanation: A variety of fine-grained micadiorite which occurs in dikes. It contains accessory quartz and augite, and generally some calcite of secondary origin.

kersey.explanation: A twilled woolen fabric, sometimes with a cotton warp, used for coats.
A garment made of this fabric.
A woolen, often ribbed fabric formerly used for hose and trousers.
A kind of coarse woolen cloth, usually ribbed, made from long wool
A kind of coarse, woolen cloth, usually ribbed, woven from wool of long staple.
A type of rough woollen cloth .

kerseymere.explanation: A fine woolen cloth with a fancy twill weave.

kerseys.explanation: Varieties of kersey; also, trousers made of kersey.

kerugma.explanation: preaching the gospel of Christ in the manner of the early church

kerwham.explanation: wham ; sound of a powerful collision

kerygma.explanation: The proclamation of religious truths, especially as taught in the Gospels.
A proclamation; preaching; specifically, Christian preaching.
The Apostolic proclamation of religious truths , especially as taught in the Gospels .
preaching the gospel of Christ in the manner of the early church

kestrel.explanation: A small falcon (Falco sparverius) found throughout the Americas, having vertical black stripes under the eyes and characteristically hovering over fields to hunt.
A small falcon (Falco tinnunculus) of Europe, Asia, and Africa that hovers when hunting and has reddish-brown plumage and a gray head.
Any of various similar falcons of the genus Falco that hover when hunting.
A common European falcon, Falco tinnunculus, Tinnunculus alaudarius , or Cerchneis tinnunculus , of small size and reddish color.

A small, slender European hawk ( Falco alaudarius ), allied to the sparrow hawk. Its color is reddish fawn, streaked and spotted with white and black. Also called windhover and stannel . The name is also applied to other allied species.
Any of various small falcons of the genus Falco that hover while hunting.
small Old World falcon that hovers in the air against a wind

ket.explanation: A matted hairy fleece of wool.
The couch- or quitch-grass, Triticum repens.
A vector , in Hilbert space , especially as representing the state of a quantum mechanical system; the complex conjugate of a bra ; a ket vector. Symbolised by |...〉.

keta.explanation: A vernacular name in Kamchatka of the dog-salmon, Oncorhynchus keta.
A small salmon ( Oncorhynchus keta ) of inferior value, which in the autumn runs up all the larger rivers between San Francisco and Kamchatka.

ketal.explanation: any acetal derived from a ketone

ketch.explanation: A two-masted fore-and-aft-rigged sailing vessel with a mizzenmast stepped aft of a taller mainmast but forward of the rudder.
An obsolete or dialectal form of catch .
A small, strongly built, twomasted vessel, usually of from 100 to 250 tons burden, but sometimes of less.
An almost obsolete form of sailing vessel, with a mainmast and a mizzenmast, -- usually from one hundred to two hundred and fifty tons burden.
In modern usage, a sailing vessel having two masts, with the main mast taller than the aftermost, or mizzen, mast.

ketch.category: Now obs. in spelling, and colloq. in pronunciation.

ketch.explanation: A fore and aft rigged sailing vessel with two masts, main and mizzen, the mizzen being stepped forward of the rudder post.
a sailing vessel with two masts; the mizzen is forward of the rudderpost

ketchup.explanation: A condiment consisting of a thick, smooth-textured, spicy sauce usually made from tomatoes.

A pureed table sauce made predominantly from tomatoes, flavored with onions, sugar, salt and spices; called also tomato ketchup . The term is also applied to pureed sauces containing mushrooms, walnuts, etc., being called in such cases mushroom ketchup , walnut ketchup , etc.
Such a sauce more generally (not necessarily based on tomatoes), or a specific brand or kind of such sauce – see usage notes below.
thick spicy sauce made from tomatoes

ketembilla.explanation: a small shrubby spiny tree cultivated for its maroon-purple fruit with sweet purple pulp tasting like gooseberries; Sri Lanka and India
maroon-purple gooseberry-like fruit of India having tart-sweet purple pulp used especially for preserves

ketene.explanation: A pungent, toxic, colorless gas, C 2 H 2 O, used chiefly as an acetylation agent.
any of a class of unsaturated ketones , having a general formula R1R2C=C=O, that react as if they were inner acid anhydrides
the parent compound of this class, CH2=C=O, an unstable , reactive colourless gas

ketimine.explanation: An imine derived from a ketone ; general formula R2C=NR

ketine.explanation: The name of a class of organic compounds containing the complex
A colorless, crystalline, basic compound, found in commercial fusel-oil and prepared by the action of ammonia on glycerol.
One of a series of organic bases obtained by the reduction of certain isonitroso compounds of the ketones. In general they are unstable oily substances having a pungent aromatic odor.

ketipic.explanation: 2 CO-COCH 2 COOH, prepared by the action of diethyl oxalate on two equivalents of ethyl dichloracetate. It decomposes at 150° C., without melting, into carbon dioxid and diacetyl. Also called diacctyl-dicarboxylic acid .

ketmie.explanation: The name of certain African species of Hibiscus, cultivated for the acid of their mucilage.
A variety of African hibiscus , cultivated for the acid of its mucilage .

keto.explanation: The carbonyl group of a ketone .

ketogenesis.explanation: The formation of ketone bodies, as occurs in diabetes mellitus.
The metabolic breakdown of fatty acids to produce ketone bodies .

ketoheptose.explanation: Any ketose form of a heptose

ketohexose.explanation: A ketone-aleohol containing 6 atoms of carbon, a member of one class of the glucoses. Fruit-sugar or levulose is the most familiar example of such a substance.
Any hexose containing an ketone group
a monosaccharide having six carbon atoms and a ketone group

ketol.explanation: The name of a class of organic compounds containing the group . They are also called ketone alcohols .
One of a series of series of complex nitrogenous substances, represented by methyl ketol and related to indol.
a weak organic base, obtained as a white crystalline substance having the odor of fæces.

ketolytic.explanation: That causes the decomposition of ketones

ketone.explanation: Any of a class of organic compounds, such as acetone, characterized by having a carbonyl group in which the carbon atom is bonded to two other hydrocarbon groups and having the general formula R(CO)R″, where R may be the same as R″.
A compound in which the carbonyl group CO unites two alcohol radicals: as, methyl-ethyl ketone , CH 3 .CO.C 2 H 5 .

One of a large class of organic substances resembling the aldehydes, obtained by the distillation of certain salts of organic acids and consisting of carbonyl (CO) united with two hydrocarbon radicals. In general the ketones are colorless volatile liquids having a pungent ethereal odor.
A homologous series of organic molecules whose functional group is an oxygen atom joined to a carbon atom—by a double bond—in a carbon-hydrogen based molecule.
any of a class of organic compounds having a carbonyl group linked to a carbon atom in each of two hydrocarbon radicals

ketonemia.explanation: An excess of ketones in the blood , sometimes associated with lipolysis .
an abnormal increase of ketone bodies in the blood as in diabetes mellitus

ketonic.explanation: Pertaining to, or derived from, a ketone.
Of, relating to, or being a ketone .

ketonization.explanation: The conversion (of a carboxylic acid , ester etc) into a ketone

ketonuria.explanation: A medical condition in which ketone bodies are present in the urine .
excessive amounts of ketone bodies in the urine as in diabetes mellitus or starvation

ketose.explanation: Any of various carbohydrates containing a ketone group.
A class-name applied in organic chemistry to sugars, such as fructose, containing a ketone group.
A saccharide containing a ketone functional group .
any monosaccharide sugar that contains a ketone group or its hemiacetal

ketosis.explanation: A pathological increase in the production of ketone bodies.

A metabolic state in which the body produces ketones to be used as fuel by some organs so that glycogen can be reserved for organs that depend on it. This condition occurs during times of fasting , starvation, or while on a ketogenic weight-loss diet.
an abnormal increase of ketone bodies in the blood as in diabetes mellitus

ketosteroid.explanation: A steroid containing a ketone group.
Any steroid having a ketone functional group
a steroid containing a ketone group

ketosuccinic.explanation: Of or pertaining to ketosuccinic acid or its derivatives

ketotic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or afflicted with ketosis

ketoxime.explanation: A class-name applied in organic chemistry to compounds of ketones and hydroxylamine, Containing the group
Any oxime derived from an ketone ; general formula R2C=NOH

kettle.explanation: A metal pot, usually with a lid, for boiling or stewing.
A teakettle.
A kettledrum.
A depression left in a mass of glacial drift, formed by the melting of an isolated block of glacial ice.
A pothole.
Same as kiddle
kittle .

A vessel of iron, copper, tin, or other metal, of various shapes and dimensions, used for boiling or heating water and other liquids, or for cooking vegetables, etc., by boiling. Compare camp-kettle, tea-kettle.
A tin pail. [Local, U. S.] A kettledrum.
figuratively, a cavity or depression suggesting the interior of a kettle.
A metallic vessel, with a wide mouth, often without a cover, used for heating and boiling water or other liguids.
ninepins; skittles.
the stitch made in sewing at the head and tail of a book.
A vessel for boiling a liquid or cooking food, usually metal and equipped with a lid .
The quantity held by a kettle.
A vessel for boiling water for tea ; a teakettle .
A kettle hole , sometimes any pothole .
A collective term for a group of raptors riding a thermal , especially when migrating .
A steam locomotive
A kettledrum .
To contain demonstrators in a confined area.
a large hemispherical brass or copper percussion instrument with a drumhead that can be tuned by adjusting the tension on it
the quantity a kettle will hold
a metal pot for stewing or boiling; usually has a lid
(geology) a hollow (typically filled by a lake) that results from the melting of a mass of ice trapped in glacial deposits

kettledrum.explanation: A large hemispherical drum, often made of copper or brass with a parchment head.
A musical instrument used in military bands and in orchestras, consisting of a hollow brass hemisphere from 24 to 30 inches in diameter, over which is stretched a head of parchment.
A fashionable afternoon entertainment given by a woman chiefly to women. It is less formal than an evening party, and the ladyguests generally wear bonnets. Also drum .
A drum made of thin copper in the form of a hemispherical kettle, with parchment stretched over the mouth of it.
An informal social party at which a light collation is offered, held in the afternoon or early evening. Cf. Drum , n., 4 and 5.
A large hemispherical brass percussion instrument (one of the timpani ) with a drumhead that can be tuned by adjusting its tension .
a large hemispherical brass or copper percussion instrument with a drumhead that can be tuned by adjusting the tension on it

kettledrummer.explanation: One who plays on a kettledrum.
A musician who plays the kettledrum .

kettleful.explanation: An amount sufficient to fill a kettle , particularly of a kettle used for cooking .
the quantity a kettle will hold

kettler.explanation: One who makes or repairs kettles; a tinker.

ketuba.explanation: Among the Jews, a written marriage contract.

ketubah.explanation: A marriage contract, traditionally written in Aramaic, stipulating certain rights and responsibilities according to Jewish laws and customs.
A traditional Jewish prenuptial agreement that outlines the rights and responsibilities of the groom in relation to the bride .

ketupa.explanation: An eared owl of Java, Strix ketupa.
[capitalized] [NL.] A genus of owls, related to the foregoing, established by Lesson in 1831; the fish-owls.

ketyl.explanation: Any of a class of organic radicals , R2C-O., formally derived from a ketone

keuper.explanation: geology , the German name of the upper division of the Triassic series, a formation of importance in Europe, and especially in Germany.
The upper division of the European Triassic. See Chart of geology .

keurboom.explanation: A species of tree, Virgilia oroboides, noted for it's pretty lilac flowers.
fast-growing roundheaded tree with fragrant white to deep rose flowers; planted as an ornamental
tree with odd-pinnate leaves and racemes of fragrant pink to purple flowers

kevel.explanation: A sturdy belaying pin for the heavier cables of a ship.
A name of Antilope kavella of Pallas, a supposed species of gazel, later identified with the common gazel, A. dorcas.
Alocalname in Derbyshire, England, for the calcareous gangue of lead ore (galena).
A strong cleat to which large ropes are belayed.
a projecting end of a timber, used as a kevel.
A strong cleat to which large ropes are belayed .

keweenawan.explanation: The name given to the series of trappean rocks and their interbedded sandstones and conglomerates in which the Lake Superior copper-mines are worked.

keweenawite.explanation: An arsenide of copper and nickel, (Cu,Ni) 2 As, found in Keweenaw county, Michigan.

kewpie.explanation: A small, fat-cheeked, wide-eyed doll with a curl of hair on top of the head.
A doll of the Kewpie brand, or any similar doll or depiction

kex.explanation: A hollow stalk, especially when dry, of various large umbelliferous plants.
The dried stem of certain large herbaceous plants.
A plant having such a stem; a weed , a kecksy .

key.explanation: A low offshore island or reef, especially in the Gulf of Mexico; a cay.
A kilogram of marijuana, cocaine, or heroin.
A notched and grooved, usually metal implement that is turned to open or close a lock.
A similar implement or an electronic device used for opening, winding, or starting something.
A device, such as a wedge or pin, inserted to lock together mechanical or structural parts.
A keycard.
A determining factor in accomplishing or achieving something.
Something that provides access to or understanding of something else.
A set of answers to a test.
A table, gloss, or cipher containing correspondences, as for decoding or interpreting something.
A number used by a cryptographic algorithm to encrypt or decrypt data.
The keystone in the crown of an arch.
A button or lever that is depressed to operate a machine.
A button that is depressed to cause a corresponding character or function to be typed or executed by a typewriter or to be accepted as input by a computer.
A button or lever that is depressed with the finger to produce or modulate the sound of an instrument, such as a clarinet or piano.
A tonal system consisting of seven tones in fixed relationship to a tonic, having a characteristic key signature and being the structural foundation of the bulk of Western music; tonality.
The principal tonality of a work.
The pitch of a voice or other sound.
A characteristic tone or level of intensity, as of a speech or sales campaign. Often used in combination.
A samara.
An outline of the distinguishing characteristics of a group of organisms, used as a guide in taxonomic identification.
An area at each end of the court between the baseline and the foul line and including the jump-ball circle at the foul line.
The act of replacing portions of a video or photograph containing a preselected color with material from a separate image, as by chroma key.
Of crucial importance; significant.
To lock with a key.
To be the determining or crucial factor in.
To furnish (an arch) with a keystone.
To regulate the pitch of.
To bring into harmony; adjust or adapt.
To cause to pay attention to.
To supply with a key of correspondences or with corresponding references.
To operate (a device), as for typesetting, by means of a keyboard.
To enter (data) into a computer by means of a keyboard.
To identify (a biological specimen).
To vandalize or mar by scratching with a key.
To produce, replace, or include by chroma key.
To pay close attention; focus.
To watch or cover an opposing player closely in an effort to limit the player's effectiveness. Used with on:
To replace portions of a video or photograph containing a preselected color with material from a separate image, as by chroma key.
( in key ) In consonance with other factors.
( out of key ) Not in consonance with other factors.
A wharf. See quay .
key up a violin.

keyboard.explanation: A panel of buttons used for typing and performing other functions on a computer or typewriter.
A row of levers that are depressed with the fingers to produce or modulate the sound of an instrument, such as a piano or organ.
Any of various instruments, played by means of a musical keyboard, often connected to a synthesizer or amplifier.
To set (copy) by means of a keyed typesetting machine.
To enter (text or data) into a computer by means of a keyboard.
To play (a composition) on a piano or keyboard.

Pedal keyboards in the organ are called radiating when the keys are made to converge somewhat below the player's seat, like the ribs of a fan, and concave when the general level of the inner keys is lower than that of the outer ones. In the best organs the pedal keyboard is both concave and radiating.
The set of keys for operating the letters of a type-writing or type-settingmachine.

In the organ, pianoforte, and similar instruments, as the harpsichord, clavichord, etc., the series or horizontal row of finger-levers or digitals (usually called keys ), by depressing which the performer causes the pipes, strings, or reeds to produce tonos.
The whole arrangement, or one range, of the keys{3} of an organ, piano, typewriter, etc.; that part of a device containing the keys{3} used to operate it.
A set of keys used to operate a typewriter , computer etc.
A component of many instruments including the piano , organ , and harpsichord consisting of usually black and white keys that cause different tones to be produced when struck.
A device with keys of a musical keyboard, used to control electronic sound-producing devices which may be built into or separate from the keyboard device.
To type on a computer keyboard.
device consisting of a set of keys on a piano or organ or typewriter or typesetting machine or computer or the like
holder consisting of an arrangement of hooks on which keys or locks can be hung

keyboarded.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of keyboard .

keyboarding.explanation: The act of typing at a keyboard (with or without a mouse or other pointing device )

keyboards.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of keyboard .

keyed.explanation: keyed flute or trombone; a keyed cithara, or harmonica. See key , 4 and .
Furnished with keys; ; also, set to a key, as a tune.
Simple past tense and past participle of key .
fitted with or secured by a key
set to a key or tone

keyhole.explanation: The hole in a lock into which a key fits.
A hole or aperture in a door or lock for receiving a key.
In carpentry , a hole or excavation passing through beams intended to be joined together, to receive the key which fastens them.—'
A small piece of water connected with a lake or other larger body; a little lake or bay.
A hole or apertupe in a door or lock, for receiving a key.
A hole or excavation in beams intended to be joined together, to receive the key which fastens them.
a mortise for a key or cotter.
a marine gastropod of the genus Fissurella and allied genera. See Fissurella .
a narrow, slender saw, used in cutting keyholes, etc., as in doors; a kind of compass saw or fret saw.
any one of numerous clypeastroid sea urchins, of the genera Melitta, Rotula, and Encope; -- so called because they have one or more perforations resembling keyholes.
The hole in a lock where the key is inserted and turns
the hole where a key is inserted

keyless.explanation: lacking or not requiring a key. Opposite of keyed .
Lacking or not requiring a key
lacking or not requiring a key

keyman.explanation: An employee of vital importance to a business .

keynesianism.explanation: the macroeconomic theories and politico-economic policies of British economist John Maynard Keynes (1883-1946) and his followers; -- used especially in reference to their advocacy of governmental action to maintain low unemployment through government spending. See Keynes .
the economic theories of John Maynard Keynes who advocated government monetary and fiscal programs intended to stimulate business activity and increase employment

keynote.explanation: The tonic of a musical key.
A prime underlying element or theme.
To give or set the keynote of.
To give a keynote address at.
In music , the tone on which a key (tonality) is founded; a tonic. See key , 7 .
A central principle or idea; the pivotal point in a system, a composition, or a course of action; a controlling thought.
The tonic or first tone of the scale in which a piece or passage is written; the fundamental tone of the chord, to which all the modulations of the piece are referred; -- called also key tone .
The fundamental fact or idea; that which gives the key.
The note on which a musical key is based.
The main theme of a speech, a written work, or a conference.
A speech that sets the main theme of a conference or other gathering; a keynote speech or keynote address.
To deliver a speech that sets the main theme of a conference or other gathering.
give the keynote address to (an audience)
(music) the first note of a diatonic scale
the principal theme in a speech or literary work

keynoted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of keynote .

keynoter.explanation: One who gives a keynote address.
A speaker who delivers the keynote speech of a conference.

keypad.explanation: An input device consisting of a set of keys that are typically numeric and arranged in a grid, as on a cell phone or calculator.
A small board with keys primarily used for tactile input into a machine .
a keyboard that is a data input device for computers; arrangement of keys is modelled after the typewriter keyboard

keypress.explanation: The depression of an input key ; a keystroke .
The buffered electrical signal resulting from such an event , sometimes distinguished from the release .

keypunch.explanation: A keyboard machine used to punch holes in cards or tapes for data-processing systems.
To process on or use such a keyboard machine.
A device, in which one or a combination of keys are pressed to punch holes in punched cards or paper tape that correspond to a particular character
an electric machine with a keyboard that has the same function
To use such a device or machine

keypunched.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of keypunch .

keypuncher.explanation: A person who operates a keypunch

keys.explanation: House of Keys , the name of the body of twenty-four representatives which constitutes the lower branch of the legislature (Court of Tynwald) of the Isle of Man.
Third-person singular simple present indicative form of key .

keyseat.explanation: To form a key seat, as by cutting. See Key seat, under key .
A bed or groove to receive a key which prevents one mechanical part from turning on another.
To form a keyseat, as by cutting .

keyset.explanation: An input device whose few keys can be pressed in many combinations , often simultaneously, to enter different commands or characters .
A set of keys ( unique identifiers ) used to distinguish the rows of data being traversed by a cursor .
A collection of keys on a typewriter or keyboard .

keystone.explanation: The central wedge-shaped stone of an arch that locks its parts together.
The central supporting element of a whole.
The stone of an arch (typically the uppermost stone), which, being the last put in, is regarded as keying or locking the whole structure together; the stone at the apex of an arch.
Hence A supporting principle; the chief element in a system; that upon which the remainder rests or depends.

In chromolithography , the first stone on which the picture is drawn or photographed, to serve as an outline guide in preparing the other stones for the colors, a copy of the keystone being made on each stone for printing a single color. See lithography .
In a Scotch lead-smelting furnace, a block of cast-iron used to close up the space at each end of the forestone, and to fill up the space between the forestone and the back part of the furnace
The central or topmost stone of an arch. This in some styles is made different in size from the other voussoirs, or projects, or is decorated with carving. See Illust. of arch .
The top stone of an arch .
A native or resident of the American state of Pennsylvania .
the central building block at the top of an arch or vault
a central cohesive source of support and stability

keystroke.explanation: A stroke of a key, as on a computer keyboard.
The act of pressing an input key ; a keypress on a computer keyboard or a typewriter , or a similar input device .
the stroke of a key; one depression of a key on a keyboard

keyway.explanation: A slot for a key in the hub or shaft of a wheel.
The keyhole of a cylinder lock.
A mortise made for the reception of a key; a slot in the round hole of a wheel for the reception of the key whereby the wheel is secured to the shaft.
A slot into which a precision attachment (a key ) is fitted

keyword.explanation: A word that serves as a key to a code or cipher.
A word used as a reference point for finding other words or information.
A word which serves as a key, guide, or explanation to the meaning, use, or pronunciation of other words, or to other matters.
A word used as an entry point into an index which serves to identify files, records, texts, or other data containing the key or some related word, such as a synonym. It is a type of key{15}.
any word used as the key to a code
Any word used in a reference work to link to other words or other information .
A reserved word used to identify a specific command , function etc.
Any word that occurs in a text more often than normal.
To tag with keywords, as for example to facilitate searching .
a significant word used in indexing or cataloging
a word that is used as a pattern to decode an encrypted message

kg.explanation: Symbol for the kilogram , an SI unit of mass equal to 103 grams .
one thousand grams; the basic unit of mass adopted under the Systeme International d'Unites

kgf.explanation: kilogram-force. A non- SI unit of force , being the force exerted on one kilogram of mass by a gravitational field of 1 standard gravity, and so equal to 9.80665 newtons

khaddar.explanation: A coarse homespun cloth made in India.
A coarse homespun cotton cloth from India .
a coarse homespun cotton cloth made in India

khadi.explanation: a coarse homespun cotton cloth made in India

khaki.explanation: A light olive brown to moderate or light yellowish brown.
A sturdy cloth of this color.
A uniform made of this cloth.
Pants made of a twilled cotton fabric of this color or another solid color.
A kind of light drab or chocolate-colored cloth used for the uniforms of some East Indian regiments.

The cause and the policy represented by the khaki-clad military forces operating in South Africa in 1899–1902, and support of the British government in its war policy at that time: as, to vote khaki , that is, to support the government and its measures in carrying on the Boer war.
The bonds issued by the British government in raising money to continue the Boer war.
Of a dull brownish yellow, or drab color; -- applied to cloth, originally to a stout brownish cotton cloth, used in making uniforms in the Anglo-Indian army.

Any kind of khaki cloth; hence, a uniform of khaki or, rarely, a soldier clad in khaki. In the United States and British armies khaki or cloth of a very similar color is almost exclusively used for service in the field.
A dull, yellowish - brown colour , the colour of dust .
Khaki green , a dull green colour.
A strong cloth of wool or cotton , often used for military or other uniforms .
A British person (from the colour of the uniform of British troops).
Dust-coloured; of the colour of dust.
a sturdy twilled cloth of a yellowish brown color used especially for military uniforms

khakis.explanation: a military uniform made of khaki fabric

khalat.explanation: A type of native gown worn in parts of Central Asia.

khalif.explanation: the civil and religious leader of a Muslim state considered to be a representative of Allah on earth

khamsin.explanation: A generally southerly hot wind originating in the Sahara that blows across Egypt from late March to early May.
A hot southeast wind that blows regularly in Egypt for about fifty days, commencing about the middle of March.
A hot wind in Egypt which blows (for about 50 days) from the desert , bringing with it sand .
an oppressively hot southerly wind from the Sahara that blows across Egypt in the spring

khamti.explanation: a branch of the Tai languages

khan.explanation: A ruler, an official, or an important person in India and some central Asian countries.

Kill, Slay, Murder, Assassinate, Slaughter, Massacre, Despatch. Kill is the general word, meaning simply to deprive of life, whether wrongfully (Ex. xx. 13), accidentally, in self-defense, in war, or by process of law. Slay is a less commonplace word with the same meaning as kill. Murder is the general word for killing wrongfully, especially with premeditation. Assassinate means to kill wrongfully by surprise, suddenly, or by secret assault. To slaughter is to kill brutally or in great numbers; massacre is more intense than slaughter , meaning to kill indiscriminately, without need or without warrant, rapidly or in great numbers. To despatch is to kill with promptness or quickness, and generally in a quiet way. Kill, slay, slaughter , and despatch may apply to ordinary and proper taking of the life of an animal. Kill and slaughter are the ordinary words used to describe the work of a butcher.

A person's nearest relatives according to the civil law. ( Stimson. ) The phrase does not include a widow, she being specifically provided for by the law as widow, and it is sometimes used in contradistinction to children: as, the widow, children, and next of kin. In either use it means that one (or more) who stands in the nearest degree of blood-relationship to the deceased. What degree is deemed nearest varies somewhat in the details of the law of different jurisdictions; but in general where there are no children, or descendants of children, the father is the next of kin, and if there is no father, the mother, and if no parent, the brothers and sisters are the next of kin, and so on.— Of kin , of the same kin; having relationship; of the same nature or kind; akin.
