kobong.explanation: In West Australia, the totem animal of a clan.

kobu.explanation: An important broad-fronded, edible seaweed, Laminaria saccharis (which see, under Laminaria ), found on the coasts of Japan, and especially of Yezo, the most northerly of the four large islands, where it is known as kombu (which see).

kobus.explanation: A genus of African antelopes of the family Bovidæ , subfamily Antilopinæ , forming part of a small group sometimes named Cervicaprinæ ; the water-bucks. It includes a number of water-antelopes called kobs. Cervicapra is a synonym.
[ lowercase ] An antelope of the genus Kobus ; a kob.

kochia.explanation: A genus of chenopodiaceous plants of the tribe Chenoleæ , characterized by a turbinate perianth, the lobes broadly winged in the fertile flowers.

kodak.explanation: A camera : a device for taking still photographs .

kodaked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kodak .

kodiak.explanation: brown bear of coastal Alaska and British Columbia
an island off southern Alaska in the Gulf of Alaska; site of the first European settlement in the area which was founded by the Russians in 1784

koechlinite.explanation: An orthorhombic-dipyramidal mineral containing bismuth , molybdenum , and oxygen .

koel.explanation: A cuckoo of the genus Eudynamys , as the Indian koel, E. orientalis. Also koϊl, kuil.
Any one of several species of cuckoos of the genus Eudynamys, found in India, the East Indies, and Australia. They deposit their eggs in the nests of other birds.
A bird of the genus Eudynamys , cuckoos from Asia, Australia and the Pacific

koellia.explanation: The genus comprising the American mountain mint, synonymous with Pycnanthemum.

koenenite.explanation: A hydrated oxychlorid of aluminium and magnesium occurring in red cleavable masses.
A trigonal-hexagonal scalenohedral mineral containing aluminum , chlorine , hydrogen , magnesium , oxygen , and sodium .

kofta.explanation: Any of various spicy meatball or meatloaf dishes of the Middle East , Caucasus , South Asia , and the Balkans .

koftgar.explanation: In India, an inlayer of steel with gold. See koftgari .

koftgari.explanation: Inlaid East Indian metal-work in steel and gold: a variety of damaskeening.
Ornamental work produced by inlaying steel with gold, -- a variety of damascening much used in the arts of India.

kohathite.explanation: In Jewish hist. , a descendant of Kohath, the second son of Levi.

kohekohe.explanation: Dysoxylum spectabile, a medium-sized tree native to New Zealand , related to mahogany .

koheleth.explanation: The book of Ecclesiastes, traditionally ascribed to King Solomon.

One of the six traditional surnames of King Solomon: said to have been applied to him because his words were spoken in public gatherings. The other five were Jedidiah, Agur, Jakah, Lemuel , and Itiel.

kohl.explanation: A cosmetic preparation, such as powdered antimony sulfide, used especially in the Middle East to darken the rims of the eyelids.
A powder used in the East from time immemorial in the toilet, to darken the orbits of the eyes, etc., properly consisting of finely comminuted antimony.
A mixture of soot and other ingredients, used by Egyptian and other Eastern women to darken the edges of the eyelids.
A dark powder used as eye makeup , especially in Eastern countries.
To decorate one's eyes with kohl or stibnite .
a cosmetic preparation used by women in Egypt and Arabia to darken the edges of their eyelids

kohlrabi.explanation: A plant (Brassica oleracea var. gongylodes) in the mustard family, having a thick basal part of the stem that is eaten as a vegetable.
A cultivar of the cabbage , Brassica oleracea , having a turnip - shaped edible stem .

kohls.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of kohl .

kohua.explanation: A three-legged iron pot or kettle; a ‘goshore’ or ‘go-ashore.’

koi.explanation: A variety of carp (Cyprinus carpio) developed in Japan and widely raised as an ornamental fish for its bright color patterns.
The common carp, Cyprinus carpio , found in the rivers of Japan.
Ornamental domesticated varieties of the common carp , Cyprinus carpio, of Japan and eastern Asia with red-gold or white coloring

koilon.explanation: In the anc. Gr. theater , the auditorium; the cavea. See cuts under cavea and diazoma.

koilonychia.explanation: A spoon-shaped finger-nail with surface concave instead of convex.
A deformity of the nails characterized by concavity of the outer surface

koine.explanation: A regional language that becomes standard over time.

koinonia.explanation: Communion by intimate participation , associated with the Christian church .
Christian fellowship or communion with God or with fellow Christians; said in particular of the early Christian community

kokako.explanation: The New Zealand wattle-crow, Callæas or Glaucopis cinerea. See Glaucopis .

kokanee.explanation: A small, landlocked sockeye salmon, often stocked in lakes.
A lacustrine (that is, land-locked, found in lakes and not in the ocean) sockeye .

kokil.explanation: A large green-billed cuckoo of India, Zanclostomus tristis. Also called malkoha .

kokio.explanation: A name in Hawaii of several species of malvaceous shrubs or trees belonging to the genus Hibiscus.

koklass.explanation: A native name of pheasants of the genus Pucrasia , which are distinguished by the long crests and ear-tufts of the males. These pheasants are found through the Himalayas from Afghanistan to Manchuria.
Any pheasant of the genus Pucrasia. The birds of this genus inhabit India and China, and are distinguished by having a long central and two lateral crests on the head. Called also pucras .
A pheasant of India and China , with a long central and two lateral crests on the head.

koko.explanation: A name in Hawaii of several shrubs and small trees belonging to the genus Euphorbia , and particularly of E. lorifolia. This is a tree 12 feet high, found at high elevations, and is much used as fire-wood.

kokoon.explanation: A tree of the genus Kokoona.

kokoona.explanation: A genus of large tropical trees growing on the islands of Ceylon and Borneo, belonging to the polypetalous order Celastrineæ , distinguished from related genera by a 3-celled ovary and winged seeds destitute of aril or albumen.

kokopu.explanation: A fish, Galaxias fasciatus , of the family Galaxidæ , found in Australian waters. See cockabully . Also sometimes applied to other fishes of the same family.

koktaite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing calcium , hydrogen , hydrogen , nitrogen , oxygen , and sulfur .

koku.explanation: A liquid and dry measure used in Japan.
A unit of measure in feudal Japan , the amount of rice needed to feed one person for a year.

kokum.explanation: Garcinia indica, a plant in the mangosteen family with culinary , pharmaceutical , and industrial uses.

kola.explanation: Any of several tropical African evergreen trees of the genus Cola, especially C. acuminata or C. nitida, cultivated for their reddish fragrant nutlike seeds, which contain caffeine and theobromine. The seeds are chewed as a stimulant and yield an extract used in pharmaceuticals and as a flavoring in foods and beverages.
A tree, genus Cola , bearing large brown nuts containing source of cola extract.
tree bearing large brown nuts containing e.g. caffeine; source of cola extract
a Chadic language spoken south of Lake Chad

kolacky.explanation: A sweet bun made from yeasted dough and usually having a fruit or poppy seed filling.

kolami.explanation: the Dravidian language spoken by the Kolam in central India

kolarian.explanation: An individual of one of the races of aboriginal inhabitants which survive in Hindustan.

kolea.explanation: The Pacific golden plover, Charadrius dominicus fulvus , which makes a wonderful trip from Alaska to the Sandwich Islands.
Hawaiian name for a migrating plover.

koli.explanation: A member of an aboriginal tribe in the hills of central India, whither they were driven by the early Aryan settlers.

kolinsky.explanation: A northern Eurasian mink (Mustela sibirica) having a dark brown coat with tawny markings.

The chorok, red sable, or Siberian mink, Putorius sibiricus , about 15 inches long, with a bushy tail 8 or 10 inches long, the fur uniformly buff or tawny, somewhat paler below, varied with black and white on the head.

Among furriers, any of several Asiatic minks; esp., Putorius sibiricus , the yellowish brown pelt of which is valued, esp. for the tail, used for making artists' brushes. Trade names for the fur are red sable and Tatar sable .
The fur of the Siberian weasel

kolo.explanation: A national folk dance in Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia, performed in a circle.

kolokolo.explanation: A name applied by the natives in Hawaii to a number of plants with a creeping or prostrate habit.

koluschan.explanation: Designating, or pertaining to, a linguistic stock of North American Indians comprising the Tlinkit tribes of the Alexander Archipelago of southeastern Alaska and adjacent coast lands. Their language bears some affinity to Mexican tongues.

komatik.explanation: A sledge used by the people of Labrador.
A rawhide -lashed sledge with wooden crossbars and runners first invented and used by the Inuit of Northern Canada, but adopted since by many non-Inuit as well.

kombu.explanation: Any of several edible kelps, especially Saccharina japonica (syn. Laminaria japonica), often used to flavor stock.

A Japanese coarse, edible seaweed, also called kobu (which see), great quantities of which are gathered on the coasts of Yezo and elsewhere and prepared for use as pickles, seasoners, relishes, vegetables, sweetmeats, and, in powdered form, as tea. See the extract.
Edible kelp used in East Asian cuisine

komi.explanation: Compensation points for the white player in the board game go .

kommos.explanation: A set of lines that alternate between an actor (or actors) and the chorus .

komondor.explanation: A Hungarian breed of large powerful shaggy-coated white dog, used also as guard dog.
Hungarian breed of large powerful shaggy-coated white dog; used also as guard dog

komtok.explanation: An African freshwater fish ( Protopterus annectens ), belonging to the Dipnoi. It can breathe air by means of its lungs, and when waters dry up, it encases itself in a nest of hard mud, where it remains till the rainy season. It is used as food.

kon.explanation: To know. See can , and con .

kona.explanation: The southwest wind that sometimes occurs in the Hawaiian Islands, interrupting the northeast trade-winds and usually bringing rain.

konak.explanation: A palace or other large official residence in Turkey or the Ottoman Empire .

kong.explanation: In the game of mahjong , a set of four identical tiles.

kongoni.explanation: A type of hartebeest from East Africa

kongsbergite.explanation: A variety of silver amalgam, containing 95 per cent. of silver, found at Kongsberg in Norway.

koninckite.explanation: A hydrated iron phosphate from Visé in Belgium.
A tetragonal mineral containing hydrogen , iron , oxygen , and phosphorus .

konini.explanation: In New Zealand, the fruit of the kotukutuku or native fuchsia, Fuchsia excorticata.
An erect deciduous shrub or tree ( Fuchsia excorticata ), native to New Zealand, growing up to 10 feet, with maroon-flushed flowers.
erect deciduous shrub or tree to 10 feet with maroon flowers; New Zealand

koniology.explanation: The science which treats of dust and its components, especially of the dust floating in the atmosphere.
the study of dust , pollen and other airborne particles.

konseal.explanation: A form of capsule for inclosing a dose of medicine that is offensive, caustic, or the like.

kontakion.explanation: A form of hymn or poem recited as a dialogue between a chanter and the choir.

koodoo.explanation: The striped antelope, Antilope strepsiceros or Strepsiceros kudu , found in many parts of Africa from Abyssinia to Cape Colony.
One of the bushbucks, Tragelaphus selousi , which inhabits the swampy regions of central and eastern Africa.

A large South African antelope ( Strepsiceros kudu ). The males have graceful spiral horns, sometimes four feet long. The general color is reddish or grayish brown, with eight or nine white bands on each side, and a pale dorsal stripe. The old males become dark bluish gray, due to the skin showing through the hair. The females are hornless. Called also nellut .
either of two spiral-horned antelopes of the African bush

kook.explanation: A person regarded as strange, eccentric, or crazy.
an eccentric , strange or crazy person ; a weirdo .
A board sport participant who has poor style or skill.
someone regarded as eccentric or crazy and standing out from a group

kookaburra.explanation: A large kingfisher (Dacelo novaeguineae) of southern and eastern Australia, having brown and white plumage and a call resembling raucous laughter.
Any of several similar kingfishers of the genera Dacelo and Clytoceyx of Australia, New Guinea, and neighboring islands.

The native name adopted as a common name for the laughing-jackass, Dacelo gigas , a large species of kingfisher. The name is extensively used about Sydney and is given by E. P. Ramsay in his “Catalogue of Australian Birds.” See cut under Dacelo .
Any of several species of kingfishers in the genus Dacelo , known for their laugh -like call.
Australian kingfisher having a loud cackling cry

kookie.explanation: informal or slang terms for mentally irregular

kookier.explanation: comparative form of kooky : more kooky

kookiest.explanation: superlative form of kooky : most kooky .

kooky.explanation: Characteristic of a kook; strange or crazy.
irreverent; idiosyncratic or unexpected; not normal
informal or slang terms for mentally irregular

koomkie.explanation: A tame female elephant used as a decoy in the capture of wild male elephants.

kootchar.explanation: An Australian stingless bee probably belonging to the genus Melipona.

kop.explanation: In Holland, the name given to the liter when used as a dry measure.

kopeck.explanation: A small Russian coin, continued as a unit of currency within the Soviet Union. One hundred kopecks make a ruble. The ruble was worth about sixty cents (U. S.) in 1910; in 1991 a two-kopeck coin could be used for a local telephone call at a pay telephone. After the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1993, the exchange value of the ruble declined rapidly and by the end of 1994 the ruble was worth three hundredths of a cent, and by 1997 two hundredths of a cent. By 1993, the kopek had become of such small value that it was obsolete and no longer minted.

kopek.explanation: A Russian unit of currency equal to 1 / 100 of the ruble.
A Russian monetary unit equal to one hundredth of a ruble .
Same as kopiyka , a Ukrainian monetary unit equal to one hundredth of a hryvnia .

koph.explanation: The nineteenth letter (P) of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding to 'the Roman q. Its numerical value is C.

kopis.explanation: A short forward curved sword in Ancient Greece used primarily as a cutting tool, but also for combat.

kopje.explanation: A hillock; a small kop, especially a small hill rising up from the African veld.
A small hill or mound (especially on the African veld ).
a small hill rising up from the African veld

koppa.explanation: A letter of the original Greek alphabet, Q , analogous in form and corresponding in position and use to the Phenician and Hebrew koph and the Latin Q, q. See episemon , 2.
The Ancient Greek letter Ϙ (lowercase ϙ ).

koppie.explanation: a small hill rising up from the African veld

koppite.explanation: A rare mineral, related to pyrochlore in composition, found at Schelin-gen in the Kaiserstuhl, Baden.

kor.explanation: an ancient Hebrew and Phoenician unit of measure of capacity
an ancient Hebrew unit of capacity equal to 10 baths or 10 ephahs

kora.explanation: A large, harplike instrument of West African origin, consisting of a hollow resonator attached to a long, notched bridge and having 21 strings that are plucked with the thumbs and index fingers of both hands.
A type of harp played in West Africa .

korahite.explanation: In Jewish hist. , a descendant of Korah (1 Chron, vi. 22, etc.), the great-grandson of Levi.

koran.explanation: Alternative spelling of Qur'an . (The Islamic holy book/bible)

koranic.explanation: of or related to the sacred texts of Islam

kore.explanation: A sculpture representing a standing young woman clothed in long robes, especially one produced in Greece before the fifth century BC.
An Ancient Greek statue of a woman, portrayed standing, usually clothed, painted in bright colours and having an elaborate hairstyle.

korfball.explanation: A non-contact unisex team sport originating from Holland , similar to netball , where players attempt to throw a ball into a basket atop a pole.
The ball used in the sport of korfball.

kori.explanation: The monetary unit of Kutch prior to 1947, divided into 24 dokda.

korimako.explanation: A Maori name for the New Zealand bell-bird, Anthornis melanura.

korin.explanation: A species of gazel, Gazella rufifrons , found in Senegal, Africa.

korma.explanation: A mild curry made from various spices especially coriander ; and often with yoghurt sauce or nuts .

kornerupine.explanation: A silicate of aluminium and magnesium, MgAl 2 SiO 6 , occurring in from colorless to white fibrous or columnar aggregates: found at Fiskernäs, Greenland. Prismatine, from Waldheim, Saxony, is a similar mineral.
A rare boro- silicate mineral with the chemical formula (Mg,Fe2+)4(Al,Fe3+)6(SiO4,BO4)5(O,OH)2, some varieties of which are valued as gemstones .

koromiko.explanation: A shrub , Hebe stricta, endemic to New Zealand .

korrel.explanation: In Holland, the name given to the decigram.

korrigan.explanation: A long-haired nocturnal and often malevolent Breton fairy princess.

korrigum.explanation: A West African antelope ( Damalis Senegalensis ), allied to the sassaby. It is reddish gray, with a black face, and a black stripe on the outside of the legs above the knees.
Damaliscus korrigum korrigum, an antelope of a subspecies of the topi .

koruna.explanation: The primary unit of currency in Slovakia before the adoption of the euro.
The currency of the former Czechoslovakia , divided into 100 hellers .
The currency of the Czech Republic , divided into 100 hellers .
The former currency of Slovakia , divided into 100 haliers .
the basic unit of money in Czech Republic
the basic unit of money in Slovakia

kos.explanation: A Jewish measure of capacity, equal to about 4 cubic inches.
an Indian unit of length having different values in different localities.
(in India) a unit of length having different values in different localities

kosha.explanation: five sheaths that are thought to cover the Atman, or True Self, according to Vedantic philosophy
a particular type of Sanskrit dictionary

kosher.explanation: Conforming to dietary laws; ritually pure.
Observing dietary laws.
Selling or serving food prepared in accordance with dietary laws.
Legitimate; permissible.
To make proper or ritually pure.
( keep kosher ) To observe Jewish dietary laws.
kosher bread, kosher meat, etc.: opposed to tref.
To prepare in conformity with the requirements of the Jewish law, as meat.
Kosher food; also, a kosher shop.
the practise of adherence to the Jewish ritual law; used mostly in the phrase keep kosher, v. i..
To adhere to the rules for eating only kosher food and handling it properly.

Ceremonially clean, according to Jewish law; -- applied to food, esp. to meat of animals slaughtered according to the requirements of Jewish law. Opposed to tref . For food to be officially kosher , it must be certified fit to eat by a Rabbi, according to Jewish ritual law.
Proper; seemly; appropriate; legitimate.
Genuine.
Prepared in accordance with Jewish religious practices .
In accordance with standards or usual practice.
to make kosher.
conforming to dietary laws
proper or legitimate
food that fulfills the requirements of Jewish dietary law

koshered.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kosher .

koshers.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of kosher .

kosin.explanation: A sulphur-yellow tasteless compound, C 23 H 30 O 7 , obtained from cusso. It does not preexist in the drug, but is a decomposition-product of kosotoxin. It is physiologically inactive. Also kussin, koussin, kosein, kussein , and tæniin.

kosotoxin.explanation: A yellowish, amorphous compound, C 26 H 34 O 10 , obtained from cusso, the pistillate flowers of the Abyssinian tree Brayera anthelmintica. It is anthelmintic.

kosteletzkya.explanation: A genus of malvaceous plants of the tribe Hibisceæ , closely related to Hibiscus , from which it differs chiefly in having only one ovule in each cell of the ovary.

koswite.explanation: In petrography , a variety of pyroxenite composed of diopsidediallage, with small amounts of olivin, hornblende, magnetite, and chrome-spinel.

kotal.explanation: In Afghanistan, a mountain pass; the summit of a pass.

kotar.explanation: a Dravidian language spoken by the Kota
a member of the Dravidian people living in the Nilgiri Hills in southern India

koto.explanation: A Japanese stringed instrument usually having 13 silk strings stretched over a long, hollow, wooden body.

A Japanese musical instrument, consisting of a long box over which are stretched thirteen strings of silk, each five feet in length and provided with a separate bridge. It is played with both hands, like the harp. The tuning is effected by shifting the position of the bridge, and semitones are obtained by pressing the string behind the bridge.

a Japanese stringed instrument having numerous strings , usually seven or thirteen, that are stretched over a convex wooden sounding board and are plucked with three plectra , worn on the thumb , index finger , and middle finger of one hand.
Japanese stringed instrument that resembles a zither; has a rectangular wooden sounding board and usually 13 silk strings that are plucked with the fingers

kotoite.explanation: A mineral form of magnesium borate that is isostructural with jimboite

kotoko.explanation: a Chadic language spoken south of Lake Chad

kotow.explanation: A knocking of the forehead on the ground while kneeling, as an act of homage, reverence, worship, respect, etc.

The prostration made by mandarins and others to their superiors, either as homage or worship, by knocking the forehead on the ground; a kowtow. There are degrees in the rite, the highest being expressed by three knockings.
To perform the kotow. Now usually spelled kowtow .
a former Chinese custom of touching the ground with the forehead as a sign of respect or submission
try to gain favor by cringing or flattering

kotowed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kotow .

kotows.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of kotow .

kotschubeite.explanation: A rose-red variety of clinochlore containing several per cent. of chromium oxid.

kotuku.explanation: The New Zealand white heron, Ardea timoriensis : like other herons miscalled a crane.

kotukutuku.explanation: In New Zealand, a small ornamental tree, Fuchsia excorticata , which belongs to the evening-primrose family.
A tree of New Zealand , Fuchsia excorticata, bearing edible purple berries .

kotwal.explanation: The leader of a kot or fort in medieval India .
The local ruler of an Indian town and its surrounding area.

kou.explanation: In the Hawaiian Islands, a name of Cordia subcordata , a tree belonging to the borage family, from which the natives make wooden bowls, or calabashes, for holding their poi.

koulan.explanation: A wild horse ( Equus onager or Asinus onager ) inhabiting the plains of Central Asia; -- called also gour , khur , and onager .
A subspecies of onager (Equus hemionus), Equus hemionus kulan.

koulibiaca.explanation: A Russian dish of salmon , rice etc. cooked in puff pastry

koumiss.explanation: An intoxicating fermented or distilled liquor originally made by the Tartars of central Asia from mare's or camel's milk. It can be obtained from any kind of milk, and is now largely made in Europe.
A fermented drink made from mare 's milk , common among peoples of the Central Asian steppes .
an alcoholic beverage made from fermented mare's milk; made originally by nomads of central Asia

kouprey.explanation: A large wild ox (Bos sauveli) of Cambodia, having a gray or blackish coat and, in the male, a large dewlap and long, spreading horns.
A wild, forest-dwelling ox , Bos sauveli, from Vietnam and surrounding countries

kouros.explanation: A sculpture representing a standing nude young man, especially one produced in Greece before the fifth century BC.
a sculpture of a naked youth in Ancient Greece, the male equivalent of a kore .

kousso.explanation: An Abyssinian rosaceous tree ( Brayera anthelmintica ), the flowers of which are used as a vermifuge.
An Abyssinian rosaceous tree whose flowers were used as a vermifuge .

kowhai.explanation: In New Zealand, either of two trees of the bean family, Sophora tetraptera and Clianthus puniceus.
A shrub or small tree ( Sophora tetraptera ) of New Zealand and Chile having pendulous racemes of tubular golden-yellow flowers; it yields a hard strong wood.
A small woody legume tree native to New Zealand that has yellow flowers . It is the national flower of New Zealand.
shrub or small tree of New Zealand and Chile having pendulous racemes of tubular golden-yellow flowers; yields a hard strong wood

kowtow.explanation: To kneel and touch the forehead to the ground in expression of deep respect, worship, or submission, as formerly done in China.
To show servile deference. synonym : fawn .
The act of kneeling and touching the forehead to the ground.
To perform the kowtow. Same as kotow

The prostration made by mandarins and others to their superiors, either as homage or worship, by knocking the forehead on the ground; same as kotow . There are degrees in the rite, the highest being expressed by three knockings.
To kneel and bow low enough to touch one’s forehead to the ground.
To act in a very submissive manner.
a former Chinese custom of touching the ground with the forehead as a sign of respect or submission
try to gain favor by cringing or flattering
bend the knees and bow in a servile manner

kowtowed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kowtow .

kowtowing.explanation: The act of one who kowtows ; a submissive bow .

koyan.explanation: A Malayan measure used in stating heavy weights, as of cargoes.

kozo.explanation: The paper-mulberry, Papyrius papyrifera. See Broussonetia .

kph.explanation: the ratio of the distance traveled (in kilometers) to the time spent traveling (in hours)

kra.explanation: The letter Κʻ or ĸ, formerly used to write the Kalaallisut language of Greenland , replaced in 1973 by the letter q .
A long-tailed ape of India and Sumatra , reddish-olive in colour with black spots and tail.

kraal.explanation: A rural village, typically consisting of huts surrounded by a stockade.

In South Africa, primarily, a collection of huts arranged around a circular inclosure for cattle, or the inclosure itself; hence, any closely built village, especially one within a stockade, or a farming establishment or ranch. Also spelled krawl .
A collection of huts within a stockade; a village; sometimes, a single hut.
An inclosure into which are driven wild elephants which are to be tamed and educated.
In Central and Southern Africa, a rural village of huts surrounded by a stockade .
a pen for livestock in southern Africa
a village of huts for native Africans in southern Africa; usually surrounded by a stockade

kraft.explanation: A tough, usually brown paper made from wood pulp treated with a solution of sodium sulfate, used chiefly for bags and wrapping paper.
strong wrapping paper made from pulp processed with a sulfur solution

krait.explanation: Any of several highly venomous snakes of the genus Bungarus of South and Southeast Asia, having a generally black body with brightly colored bands.
A small snake, Bungarus cæruleus or B. candidus , extremely venomous, and common throughout the greater part of the Indian subregion.
A very venomous snake of India ( Bungarus cœruleus ), allied to the cobra. Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often with narrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.
Any of several brightly-coloured, venomous snakes , of the genus Bungarus , of southeast Asia.
brightly colored venomous but nonaggressive snake of southeastern Asia and Malay peninsula

kraken.explanation: A huge sea monster in Norwegian legend.
A mythical sea-monster said to appear at times off the coast of Norway.
A fabulous Scandinavian sea monster, often represented as resembling an island, but sometimes as resembling an immense octopus.

krakowiak.explanation: A lively Polish dance. See cracovienne .
A lively , syncopated Polish dance in duple time.

krama.explanation: The mixture of water and wine used in the eucharist, especially by the Greek and Roman Catholic churches. See krasis .

krameria.explanation: Any member of the genus Krameria of rhatanies .

kran.explanation: The monetary unit of Persia and a current coin, valued at ⅞10 United States cents or one tenth of a toman.

krang.explanation: In whaling , the carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.
The carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.
The carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.

krans.explanation: The overhang of a cliff; a precipitous wall of rock which surrounds a valley. Also krantz .

krantz.explanation: An encircling or overhanging wall of rock

krantzite.explanation: A mineral resin from Nienburg in Hanover, near amber in composition.

krasis.explanation: The act of adding a little water to the wine used for the eucharist: a primitive practice recognized in all ancient liturgies except the Armenian, mentioned by St. Justin Martyr (writing about a. d. 139) and other early writers, and believed by most liturgiologists to date from Christ's institution of the sacrament. Also called mixture .

krater.explanation: A wide, two-handled bowl used in ancient Greece and Rome for mixing wine and water.
An ancient Greek vessel for mixing water and wine.

kraunhia.explanation: A genus of climbing leguminous plants commonly known as Wistaria (which see).

kraurosis.explanation: In pathology , a dry, shriveled condition of a part.
atrophy and shriveling of the skin or mucous membrane

krausite.explanation: A monoclinic-prismatic mineral containing hydrogen , iron , oxygen , potassium , and sulfur .

kraut.explanation: Used as a disparaging term for a person of German birth or ancestry.
offensive term for a person of German descent

krauthead.explanation: offensive term for a person of German descent

krautweed.explanation: Either of two cruciferous plants, Brassica arvensis , the char-lock, also called crowdweed , and Raphanus Raphanistrum , the wild radish, sometimes called white charlock .

kreittonite.explanation: A variety of gahnite, or zinc spinel, from Bodenmais in Bavaria, containing 17 per cent. of iron sesquioxid.

kremersite.explanation: A chlorid of iron, potassium, ammonium, and sodium, found as a sublimation product at Vesuvius.
An orthorhombic-dipyramidal mineral containing chlorine , hydrogen , hydrogen , iron , nitrogen , oxygen , and potassium .

kremlin.explanation: A Russian ‘ castle ’ or fortified, central complex, as found in various Russian cities.

krems.explanation: A variety of white lead. See Krems lead, under lead , n.

krennerite.explanation: A rare tellurid of gold and silver occurring in orthorhombic crystals at Nagyag in Transylvania. Sometimes called bunsenite .
An orthorhombic-pyramidal creamy white mineral containing gold and tellurium .

kreplach.explanation: Small pockets of noodle dough filled with ground meat or cheese, usually boiled and served in soups.
Small dumplings of Eastern European origin, filled with meat or cheese and served usually in soup .

kreutzer.explanation: A coin formerly current in Germany, struck in silver and copper, and worth less than 2 United States cents.
A modern copper coin of Austria, the one hundredth part of the florin, equal to nearly half of a United States cent. Also spelled creutzer .
A small copper coin formerly used in South Germany; also, a small Austrian copper coin.
A medieval silver coin once used as currency in southern Germany and Austria .

kreuzer.explanation: Any of several small coins of low value formerly used in Austria and Germany.

kriegspiel.explanation: A game in which blocks representing bodies of soldiers are moved on a map: designed to illustrate the art of war.
A game designed to teach the principles of strategy and tactics.
A boardgame used to train military tactics and strategy
A variant of chess in which players cannot see their opponent's pieces

krieker.explanation: A name in Rhode Island, Long Island, and New Jersey of the pectoral sandpiper, Tringa maculata. Also called squat-snipe and squatter.

krigia.explanation: A genus of North American liguliflorous composite plants, of the tribe Cichoriaceæ , subtribe Hyoserideæ with yellow flowers, usually on leafless scapes, a few-bracted involucre, many-ribbed achenes, and pappus of 5 to 8 small chaffy scales, alternating with as many bristles.
any small branched yellow-flowered North American herb of the genus Krigia

krill.explanation: The collection of small marine crustaceans of the order Euphausiacea that are the principal food of baleen whales.
any of several small marine crustacean species of plankton in the order Euphausiacea in the class Malacostraca
shrimp-like planktonic crustaceans; major source of food for e.g. baleen whales

krimmer.explanation: Gray, curly fur made from the pelts of lambs of the Crimean region.

kris.explanation: A Malay or Indonesian dagger having a wavy double-edged blade.
An Indonesian or Malay dagger with a wavy, or rigid serpentine blade.
A Moro sword with an asymmetrical blade.
a Malayan dagger with a wavy blade

krishnaism.explanation: worship of Krishna the 8th avatar of Vishnu

krishnaist.explanation: One who worships the Hindu deity Krishna. See Krishna and Krishnaism .

krisuvigite.explanation: A variety of the basic copper sulphate brochantite, found at Krisuvig in Iceland.

kritarchy.explanation: The rule of the judges over the people of Israel.
The rule of the judges over Israel.

krobylos.explanation: In Greek antiquity , a roll or knot of hair on the head.

kromskop.explanation: A trade-name of the chromascope (which see).

krona.explanation: the basic unit of money in Iceland
the basic unit of money in Sweden

krone.explanation: The currency of Denmark or Norway , divided into 100 øre

kroo.explanation: One of a stalwart negro race on the coast of Liberia, distinguished for skill as seamen.

kroon.explanation: The primary unit of currency in Estonia before the adoption of the euro.
The former currency of Estonia , divided into 100 senti
the basic unit of money in Estonia

krubi.explanation: malodorous tropical plant having a spathe that resembles the corolla of a morning glory and attains a diameter of several feet

krummholz.explanation: An area of stunted windblown trees growing at high elevations on mountain slopes.
Dense low matted bushes at the tree-line .

krummhorn.explanation: A wind instrument of the Renaissance with a curving tube and a double reed.
A medieval musical instrument of the clarinet class, having a curved tube and a melancholy tone.
In organ-building , a reed-stop with short, slender metal pipes, and a tone like that of the clarinet. Also called clarinet-stop, cromorna , and corruptly cremona.
A reed instrument of music of the cornet kind, now obsolete (see cornet , 1, a.).
A reed stop in the organ; -- sometimes called cremona .
a mediaeval and Renaissance wind instrument
a Renaissance woodwind with a double reed and a curving tube (crooked horn)

kryptol.explanation: A trade-name for a loose, granular material, a mixture of graphite, carborundum, and fire-clay, having a high electrical resistance.

krypton.explanation: A colorless, largely inert gaseous element used chiefly in gas discharge lamps and fluorescent lamps. Atomic number 36; atomic weight 83.80; melting point −157.36°C; boiling point −153.34°C; density 3.733 grams per liter (0°C). cross-reference : Periodic Table .
A chemical element, one of the five recently discovered gaseous constituents of the atmosphere, first obtained by Ramsay and Travers in 1898.

An inert gaseous element of the argon (noble gas) group, of atomic number 36, occurring in air to the extent of about one volume in a million. It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898. Boiling point, -152.3° C.; melting point, -156.6° C.; symbol, Kr; atomic weight, 83.8.
A chemical element (symbol Kr) with an atomic number of 36; one of the noble gases .
a colorless element that is one of the six inert gasses; occurs in trace amounts in air

kryptonite.explanation: The one weakness of something or someone that is otherwise invulnerable, an Achilles' heel .

ksar.explanation: a granary , or village containing a granary, in the Mahgreb

kshatriya.explanation: The second-highest of the four castes or varnas in traditional Indian society: the warrior or military caste. (Plural: kshatriya.)

kt.explanation: the unit of measurement for the proportion of gold in an alloy; 18-karat gold is 75% gold; 24-karat gold is pure gold

kuchen.explanation: A coffeecake raised with yeast, often containing fruit and nuts.
Any of several types of cake , typically eaten with coffee

kudo.explanation: A praising remark; an accolade or compliment.

kudos.explanation: Acclaim or praise for exceptional achievement.
To praise; to extol; to glorify.
an expression of approval and commendation

kudu.explanation: Either of two large African antelopes (Tragelaphus strepsiceros or T. imberbis) having a brownish or grayish coat with white vertical stripes and, in the male, long, spirally curved horns.
A large, striped, African antelope of the species Tragelaphus imberbis (the lesser kudu) or Tragelaphus strepsiceros (the greater kudu)
either of two spiral-horned antelopes of the African bush

kudzu.explanation: An East Asian vine (Pueraria lobata) in the pea family, having compound leaves and clusters of reddish-purple flowers. It is grown for fodder, forage, and root starch, and is a widespread weed in the southeast United States.
An Asian vine grown as a root starch and sometimes considered a noxious weed.

fast-growing vine from eastern Asia having tuberous starchy roots and hairy trifoliate leaves and racemes of purple flowers followed by long hairy pods containing many seeds; grown for fodder and forage and root starch; widespread in the southern United States

kuge.explanation: A court noble of Japan, as distinguished from a daimio or territorial noble, or such court nobles collectively. See buke .

kugel.explanation: A baked pudding of noodles or potatoes, eggs, and seasonings, traditionally eaten by Jews on the Sabbath.
A baked pudding of rice , pasta , or potatoes with vegetables or raisins and spices ; a traditional Jewish dish.
A traditional house ornament made of glass.
An overly materialistic and excessively groomed young woman.

kuhnia.explanation: A genus of American herbs, of the composite family, tribe Eupatoriaceæ , and subtribe Adenostyleæ , having the scales of the involucre imbricated in several series, the lobes of the corolla short, the bristles of the pappus plumose, the heads middle-sized and panicled, and the leaves alternate.

kui.explanation: the Dravidian language spoken by the Kui in southeastern India
a member of the Dravidian people living in southeastern India

kuichua.explanation: A kind of wild cat, Felis macrurus , found in Brazil, notable for the length of its tail. It is one of a number of spotted cats, resembling the ocelot, indigenous to South America.

kujawiak.explanation: A Polish dance resembling the mazurka; also, tho music for such a dance.

kukang.explanation: The Javan slow lemur or slow-paced lori, Stenops ( Nycticebus ) javanicus , a prosimian quadruped of the family Lemuridæ and subfamily Nycticebinæ.

kukeri.explanation: A sword used by the Goorkhas of India.

kuki.explanation: Kamarupan languages spoken in western Burma and Bangladesh and easternmost India

kukri.explanation: A large knife with a somewhat sickle-shaped blade that is broader near its point than near the hilt, used especially by Gurkha soldiers as a weapon and cutting tool.
A curved Nepalese knife used especially by Gurkha fighters.

kuku.explanation: A large and handsome fruit-pigeon. Carpophaga novæ-zelandiæ , found in New Zealand.

kukui.explanation: In Hawaii, the candlenut-tree, Aleurites Moluccana , which is easily recognized among the trees of the forest by its silvery foliage.

kula.explanation: A tower , turret or a steeple on the Balkans erected during the period of Ottoman domination on the area.

kulaite.explanation: A group of basalts from the Kula basin, Asia Minor, containing more hornblende than augite, and differing in the kinds of feldspathic constituents.

kulak.explanation: A prosperous landed peasant in czarist Russia, characterized by the Communists during the October Revolution as an exploiter.
A prosperous peasant in the Russian Empire or the Soviet Union, who owned land and could hire workers.

kulanapan.explanation: a group of languages of the Hokan family

kuli.explanation: In southern India, hire; wages. Also spelled culy .

kultur.explanation: German culture or civilization , especially seen as authoritarian or racist during the period of world wars (1914-18 and 1939-45)

kulturkampf.explanation: A conflict between secular and religious authorities, especially the struggle between the Roman Catholic Church and the German government under Bismarck .

kumara.explanation: The aboriginal name in New Zealand for the sweet potato.

kumis.explanation: an alcoholic beverage made from fermented mare's milk; made originally by nomads of central Asia

kumiss.explanation: The fermented milk of a mare or camel, used as a beverage by certain peoples of western and central Asia.

A common beverage of the nomads of northern Asia, consisting of fermented mares' milk, resembling sour buttermilk, but clear and free from greasiness. The Kirghiz and others distil an intoxicating liquor from it.

A fermented dietetic and sanitary drink made in western countries, in imitation of the preceding, from cows' milk with sugar and yeast, and allowed to ferment until it becomes effervescent and slightly alcoholic.

kummel.explanation: A cordial made especially in the Baltic provinces of Russia, flavored with cumin, caraway, or fennel, and generally much sweetened. The best quality is called allasch .
A Russian and German liqueur, consisting of a sweetened spirit flavored with caraway seeds.
liqueur flavored with caraway seed or cumin

kumquat.explanation: Any of several trees or shrubs of the genus Fortunella, having small, edible, orangelike fruit.
The fruit of any of these plants, having an acid pulp and a thin, edible rind.

any of several trees or shrubs of the genus Fortunella (formerly Citrus) of the rue family ( Rutaceae ) (especially Citrus Japonica ) growing in China and Japan bearing small orange-colored edible fruits with thick sweet-flavored skin and sour pulp; also, any of the small acid, orange-colored citrus fruits of such plants, used mostly for preserves.
A small, orange citrus -like fruit which is native to Asia.
any of several trees or shrubs of the genus Fortunella bearing small orange-colored edible fruits with thick sweet-flavored skin and sour pulp
small oval citrus fruit with thin sweet rind and very acid pulp

kunai.explanation: A Japanese tool and weapon, possibly derived from the masonry trowel, used as a weapon by ninja (or samurai ).

kundalini.explanation: Energy that lies dormant at the base of the spine until it is activated, as by the practice of yoga, and channeled upward through the chakras in the process of spiritual perfection.
yoga An energy said to lie coiled at the base of the spine , which can be released by yoga .

kunzite.explanation: A lilac-colored spodumene used as a gemstone.
A transparent pink-and-purple lilac variety of spodumene.
Kunzite is a pink to lilac colored gemstone, a variety of spodumene .
a pinkish lilac crystal form of the mineral spodumene that is used as a gemstone

kupfernickel.explanation: The common German name of the mineral niccolite: so called because, though an ore of nickel, it has a coppery-red color.

kupfferite.explanation: A magnesium silicate belonging to the amphibole or hornblende group. It occurs in prismatic masses having an emerald-green color, due to the presence of a small amount of chromium.

kurbash.explanation: A whip or strap about a yard in length.

kurchatovium.explanation: A transuranic element of atomic number 104, symbol Ku; also called rutherfordium , symbol Rf. It is produced in very small quantities by nuclear reactions. In November 1993 the nomenclature committe of the American Chemical Society approved the name rutherfordium for element 104. Russsian investigators who claim to have first discovered element 104, isotope 260 (half-life 0.3 seconds) in 1964 at Dubna proposed the name kurchatovium . However, investigators at Berkely in 1969 produced several isotopes of element 104 but were unable to produce isotope 260; they reported finding isotope 257, with a half-life of 4-5 seconds, isotope 259 with a half-life of 3-4 seconds, and isotope 258 with a shorter half-life.

kurgan.explanation: A type of tumulus or barrow characteristic of a culture located on the steppes of southern Russia about 5000 BC and later spreading to the Danube, northern Europe, and northern Iran from around 3500 BC.
The culture that produced these tumuli or barrows.
A member of the people or peoples sharing this culture. The earliest Kurgans are considered by some to be speakers of Proto-Indo-European.
A prehistoric burial mound once used by peoples in Siberia and Central Asia .

kurilian.explanation: A native of the Kurile Islands.
Of or pertaining to the Kurile Islands, a chain of islands in the Pacific ocean, extending from the southern extremity of Kamchatka to Yesso.

kuroshio.explanation: A swift, intense current that flows northeastward off the coasts of China and Japan ; part of the North Pacific subtropical gyre.

kurrajong.explanation: Any of several Australian trees of the genus Brachychiton, especially B. populneus, having yellowish or reddish flowers and woody seed pods, and often planted as an ornamental.

Same as currajong : the name is also applied to a number of other malvaceous and sterculiaceous trees or shrubs yielding strong bast-fibers from which the natives make cordage, nets, or matting. See the phrases below.
Any of a number of species of tree or shrub in the genus Brachychiton.
widely distributed tree of eastern Australia yielding a tough durable fiber and soft light attractively grained wood; foliage is an important emergency food for cattle

kursaal.explanation: A public hall or room for the use of visitors at many German watering-places or health resorts. Reading-rooms and rooms for recreation are usually associated with the kursaal.
A public hall or room, for the use of visitors at watering places and health resorts in Germany.
A public hall or building for the use of visitors at health resorts or spas ; a casino

kurta.explanation: A loose long-sleeved shirt or tunic, often extending to the knees, worn primarily in South Asia.
A traditional article of clothing worn in Afghanistan , Bangladesh , India , Pakistan , and Sri Lanka , consisting of a loose, collarless , long-sleeved, knee-length shirt worn by both men and women.
a loose collarless shirt worn by many people on the Indian subcontinent (usually with a salwar or churidars or pyjama)

kurtosis.explanation: A quantity indicating how sharply a probability distribution function increases and decreases around the distribution's mean.
A measure of "peakedness" of a probability distribution , defined as the fourth cumulant divided by the square of the variance of the probability distribution.

kuru.explanation: A fatal degenerative disease of the brain caused by a prion, formerly found among certain peoples of New Guinea and transmitted by the consumption of human flesh during mortuary rites.

A chronic , progressive , fatal central nervous system disease found mainly among the Fore and neighboring peoples of New Guinea , caused by a prion that probably resembles the scrapie agent of sheep, transmissible to nonhuman primates, and believed to be transmitted by ritual cannibalism .

a progressive disease of the central nervous system marked by increasing lack of coordination and advancing to paralysis and death within a year of the appearance of symptoms; thought to have been transmitted by cannibalistic consumption of diseased brain tissue since the disease virtually disappeared when cannibalism was abandoned

kuruma.explanation: A Japanese cart; a vehicle of any kind, including the jinrikisha.

kurus.explanation: A subdivision of currency, equal to a 1/100th of a Turkish lira .

kurveyor.explanation: In South Africa, a traveling carrier or trader who carries the goods of others from one point to another in his heavy ox-wagon, and who also peddles his own wares.

kusan.explanation: a Penutian language spoken by the Kusan
a member of the North American Indian people of Oregon

kusimanse.explanation: A small West African civet-cat, Crossarchus obscurus.
A carnivorous animal ( Crossarchus obscurus ) of tropical Africa. It its allied to the civets. Called also kusimansel , and mangue .
Several species of dwarf mongoose in genus Crossarchus.

kusti.explanation: A woolen cord worn by Parsees of both sexes, consisting of seventy-two threads, that being the number of the chapters of the Izashne, with two branches having twelve knots for the months of the year.

kusum.explanation: The safflower, Carthamus tinctorius. See Carthamus .

kutcha.explanation: Dried brick or mud , used as a material.

kuttar.explanation: A sort of short dagger, peculiar to India, having a handle consisting of two parallel bars with a crosspiece connecting them. The hand is inserted to grip the crosspiece, and the bars serve as a guard to the wrist.

kuvasz.explanation: long-established Hungarian breed of tall light-footed but sturdy white dog; used also as a hunting dog

kv.explanation: a unit of potential equal to a thousand volts

kvass.explanation: A Russian fermented beverage similar to beer, made from rye or barley.
A fermented drink in general use in Russia, taking the place of the beer of other countries.
A type of traditional fermented Russian beverage with little or no alcohol, made from bread, often flavored with fruit.
fermented beverage resembling beer but made from rye or barley

kvetch.explanation: Person who endlessly whines or complains.
Person who finds fault with anything.
To whine or complain, often needlessly.
express complaints, discontent, displeasure, or unhappiness

kvetched.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kvetch .

kvetches.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of kvetch .

kw.explanation: a unit of power equal to 1000 watts

kwacha.explanation: Malawi 's major currency unit; 100 tambala = 1 kwacha.
Zambia 's major currency unit; 100 ngwee = 1 kwacha.
the basic unit of money in Zambia
the basic unit of money in Malawi

kwan.explanation: A silver coin of Annam and Cambodia, equivalent to a string of 600 cash or to 4 francs.
A Japanese unit of weight, equal to 1,000 momme or 8.28 pounds avoirdupois.

kwashiorkor.explanation: Severe protein malnutrition, especially in children after weaning, marked by lethargy, growth retardation, anemia, edema, potbelly, skin depigmentation, and hair loss or change in hair color.
A form of malnutrition , found in children, caused by dietary insufficiency of protein in combination with a high carbohydrate diet.
severe malnutrition in children resulting from a diet excessively high in carbohydrates and low in protein

kwazoku.explanation: One of the two classes of modern Japanese nobility, corresponding to the old territorial nobility.

kwela.explanation: A kind of danceable music popular among black South Africans; it includes a whistle among its instruments.
A style of music first played in the townships whose principal instrument is the penny whistle .
a kind of danceable music popular among black South Africans; includes a whistle among its instruments

ky.explanation: An obsolete or dialectal plural of cow .
a state in east central United States; a border state during the American Civil War; famous for breeding race horses

kyack.explanation: A packsack that hangs on either side of a packsaddle.
A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.
a packsack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle

kyang.explanation: The wild ass of Tibet, Equus hemionus. It is over four feet high at the shoulder, of a dark-reddish color, with a narrow stripe along the back.

kyanite.explanation: A bluish-green to colorless mineral, Al 2 SiO 5 , used as a refractory.
a blue neosilicate mineral , Al2SiO5, found in metamorphic rocks
a grey or greenish-blue mineral consisting of aluminum silicate in crystalline form; occurs in metaphoric rock, used as a refractory

kyanization.explanation: The act or process of kyanizing .

kyanize.explanation: To render (wood) proof against decay by saturating with a solution of corrosive sublimate in open tanks, or under pressure.
To preserve wood from decay by soaking it in a solution of mercuric chloride

kyanized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of kyanize .

kyanizing.explanation: A process for preventing the decay of wood, patented by J. H. Kyan in 1832.

kyanol.explanation: A base obtained from coal tar.
A base obtained from coal tar .

kyar.explanation: Cocoanut fiber, or the cordage made from it. See coir .

kyat.explanation: the basic unit of money in Myanmar

kylix.explanation: A shallow, stemmed, two-handled drinking cup of ancient Greece.

In Greek antiquity , a vase or cup of elegant form, used for drinking. The kylix was usually broad and shallow, with or without a slender foot, and provided with two handles not extending above the rim. Also written cylix .
An Ancient Greek drinking cup with a stem, two handles, and a broad, shallow body
a shallow drinking cup with two handles; used in ancient Greece

kyloe.explanation: One of the cattle of the Hebrides.
A breed of small Highland cattle .

kymogram.explanation: A graph or record made by a kymograph.
A graphical record produced by a kymograph

kymograph.explanation: An instrument for recording variations in pressure, as of the blood, or in tension, as of a muscle, by means of a pen or stylus that marks a rotating drum.
An instrument by means of which variations of fluid pressure, as of the blood in some one of the vessels of a living animal, can be measured and graphically recorded.
An instrument for measuring, and recording graphically, the pressure of the blood in any of the blood vessels of a living animal; -- called also kymographion .
A device that gives a graphical representation of a variation in a phenomenon such as blood pressure over time, using a pen on a rotating drum .
scientific instrument consisting of a rotating drum holding paper on which a stylus traces a continuous record (as of breathing or blood pressure)

kymographic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a kymograph.
Of or pertaining to a kymograph .

kynurenic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from the urine of dogs. By decomposition the acid yields a nitrogenous base (called kynurin ) and carbonic acid.
Of or pertaining to kynurenic acid or its derivatives

kyoodle.explanation: A mutt , dog of mixed breed of little value; noisy dog.

kyphoscoliosis.explanation: Combined lateral and posterior curvature of the spine.
Abnormal curvature of the spine in both coronal and sagittal planes .

kyphosis.explanation: Abnormal rearward curvature of the spine, resulting in protuberance of the upper back; hunchback.
In pathology , a curvature of the spine, convex backward. Also written cyphosis .
An abnormal curvature of the spine, causing a hunchback .
an abnormal backward curve to the vertebral column

kyphotic.explanation: characteristic of or suffering from kyphosis, an abnormality of the vertebral column

kyrie.explanation: A short prayer or petition including the phrase kyrie, meaning "Lord, have mercy".
: A setting of the traditional kyrie text to music for a Mass .

kyrielle.explanation: A verse form in French poetry, divided into equal couplets ending with the same word, which serves as a refrain.
A litany beginning with the words, “Kyrie eleison.”
A form of poem written in rhyming couplets or quatrains , sometimes with a religious theme.

kythe.explanation: To come into view; to appear.
To make known; to manifest; to show; to declare.

kytoon.explanation: A lighter-than-air kite , filled with gas and capable of staying aloft even without wind .

kyu.explanation: A grade or rank in Japanese martial arts .
